When *hun* and *po* unite in essence, *qian* and *kun* share the same lifespan. In aiding others and engaging with the world, your virtue will grow, and even gods and spirits will revere you.”

Cultivate the self with an empty heart, and the Dao’s height subdues dragon and tiger. When all the dusts and leaks of Jambudvīpa are exhausted, afflictions vanish entirely. The true joy of immortals is no fleeting thing—only through skillful means does one attain great freedom, and this is the foremost accumulation of merit.

Yellow sprouts and white snow are not hard to find, yet the enlightened must rely on deep virtue. The Four Symbols and Five Phases depend wholly on earth; how could the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams ever depart from *ren*? When the numinous essence is refined, people fail to recognize it; when all demons are dissolved, ghosts dare not intrude. Should one wish to leave secret formulas among humankind, not a single soul would prove a true confidant.

**Dao Guang says:** The dragon’s string of *qi* is called white snow; the tiger’s string of *qi* is called yellow sprouts. The root of the great elixir truly lies herein. The Dao is utterly simple, its affairs not remote. Yet without grand merit and mighty deeds, one cannot encounter a true teacher to point out the profound mysteries.

The Dao arises from emptiness and gives birth to the One *qi*; the One *qi* transforms into yin and yang, called dragon and tiger. The dragon, wood, generates fire; the tiger, metal, generates water. Wood, fire, metal, and water combine to form the Four Symbols. When the Four Symbols unite, the great elixir is completed—its completion truly depends on earth. Earth has no fixed form; it divides its position among the four seasons and four times. Without the true earth of the four seasons, the four sequences cannot proceed, and how could creation arise? Thus, the Four Symbols and Five Phases rely entirely on earth.

*Ren* is water, the true One *qi* born before heaven and earth, transforming into yang-dragon and yin-tiger to merge and form the elixir. The elixir is earth; the dragon is wood; the tiger is metal—these are called the Three Natures. The Three Origins do not depart from the transformation of the true One’s water. The Eight Trigrams are the true One’s *qi*: first, it transforms into heaven, called *Qian*, the father; second, it transforms into earth, called *Kun*, the mother. *Qian*, with its yang *qi*, seeks *Kun*’s yin *qi*—once sought, it gives birth to the eldest son, *Zhen*; twice sought, the middle son, *Kan*; thrice sought, the youngest son, *Gen*. This is *Qian* uniting with *Kun* to give birth to the three yang. *Kun*, with its yin *qi*, seeks *Qian*’s yang *qi*—once sought, it gives birth to the eldest daughter, *Xun*; twice sought, the middle daughter, *Li*; thrice sought, the youngest daughter, *Dui*. This is *Kun* uniting with *Qian* to give birth to the three yin. All do not depart from the transformation of the true One’s water, hence: how could the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams ever depart from *ren*?

Not only do the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams not depart from the essence of the true One, but since the beginning of creation, all that has form arises from this and transforms. The cultivator who obtains the true One’s water has accomplished all things. When the true One’s water is transformed by method into the true One’s grain of millet, swallowed into the cinnabar field and fired for ten months, all yin is smelted away. The pure yang immortal of the true One—yin demons, corpse-ghosts flee with no escape. When the root of goodness is planted, the numinous bone grows; when the numinous bone grows, immortality may be hoped for. The growth of the numinous bone is the planting of the root of goodness—not in one or two lifetimes, but through countless eons, accumulating all good roots. How could one, having just emerged, already bear the ethereal air of transcending the dust?

Alas! Wandering ghosts and moving corpses, with a single bottle and bowl, may wish to ascend as immortals—yet immortals are not easily attained. Why not examine one’s own heart and ask whether it differs from the common heart? My immortal affairs also have their limits. One must broadly transform and adapt, taking the Dao as one’s duty, standing alone above the world, a crane among chickens. Though people laugh at me as wild and unrestrained, I know I am no ordinary sort. Red Pine and yellow essence are my friends; Penglai and Fangzhang are my home. Naturally, one will encounter perfected beings, receive the transmission of the supreme Dao, unite with kindred spirits, and with earnest care, complete the elixir.

The immortal elder wished to leave secret teachings among humankind—yet how could he meet his Ziyu? How might one find another like myself?

**Ziye says:** Yellow sprouts are the essence of lead; white snow is the *qi* of mercury. Those who seek them must possess virtue. Earth is *wu* and *ji*; *ren* is the true One’s water, the ancestral *qi* that gives life to all things.

**Shangyangzi says:** Yellow sprouts and white snow are the true One’s *qi* produced within primal darkness. Earlier, it was said that true lead must be diligently sought—here, it is said that yellow sprouts and white snow are not hard to find, for they depend on virtue. Foolish disciples see these two verses as contradictory, yet they do not know that without virtue, this Dao can never complete the elixir. The proverb says: “If your words are pure but your conduct is turbid, do not speak of the Dao.” One who knows the Dao but has not accumulated virtue is like a fish without water, a lamp without oil—how could the returning elixir be achieved? The Four Symbols, Five Phases, Three Origins, and Eight Trigrams have many names, yet none can do without the true One’s *ren*-water.

My Yellow Chamber Master praised the Old Immortal of Pure Yang, saying: “The crucible gathers the Four Symbols and Five Phases; the medicine follows the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams. The red phoenix spits the marrow of the southern direction; the black turtle holds the essence of the northern sea.” This is what he meant—all trace back to the verse of Pure Yang: “The crucible follows the center of the four seasons; the medicine moves with the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams.” The same idea.

Though the true immortal sages and teachers are compassionate in guidance, it truly depends on one’s own conduct. Once this elixir is completed, the Jade Emperor bestows praise, and the ten thousand spirits of heaven and earth all revere it—hence its name: the Supreme Perfected Numinous Treasure, the Wondrous Nine-Return Great Elixir. Long ago, the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginning expounded the scriptures to save beings; the empty platform of the mysterious seat suspended a treasure pearl as large as a grain of millet—this was it. The Mahāyāna Prajñā’s nine-grade lotus dais, the luminous treasury, the wish-fulfilling wondrous Dharma, the numinous-responsive *maṇi* jewel—this was the pearl the dragon girl offered at the Vulture Peak assembly. Its preciousness cannot be described—how could the people of the world recognize it?

When the elixir is completed, the body becomes sacred, and the yang spirit manifests—this is called the Perfected One. The yin demons and ghostly thieves transform into guardian deities; the Green Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior within the body, along with the three *hun*, seven *po*, Three Origins and Nine Palaces, Three Divisions and Eight Sceneries, five viscera and eight consciousnesses, all become spirits. The thirty-six thousand radiant essences transform into divine soldiers.

At that time, the Immortal Elder wished to transmit the secret oral instructions to others, yet in an entire generation, few would believe, receive, and practice them. Alas! To bow to a master while still bound in fetters—such are the disciples who come after the Apricot Grove.

Grasses and trees, too, balance yin and yang;
If either is lacking, no fragrance will bloom.
First, green leaves unfold as yang takes the lead,
Then red flowers follow as yin comes along.
This is the common Way, our daily practice—
Yet who knows the true source’s reversals and turns?

The Radiance of the Dao says: Before grasses and trees sprout, they contain the purest simplicity. When their husks split, they receive the one qi to germinate, thus drawing forth a single leaf to symbolize that one qi. Next, two leaves divide to represent yin and yang, and from between them emerges another leaf to correspond to the Three Powers. Beyond this, they gradually grow lush: in spring, green leaves appear; in summer, red flowers bloom—this is the work of yang qi. In autumn, they wither and bear fruit; in winter, they die back to their roots—this is the work of yin qi. When yin and yang are balanced, generation never ceases; if either is lacking, the myriad things cannot arise.

True Unity Master says: Solitary yin cannot generate itself; solitary yang cannot complete itself. Thus, when heaven and earth intermingle in misty vapor, the myriad things transform and harmonize. When male and female unite in essence, the myriad things are born. This is the common Way, our daily practice.

As for the true source’s reversals: there is a profound mechanism of inversion and mutual exchange. If scholars do not understand this, how can they transcend life and death?

Ziye says: The Way of the Golden Elixir is like the yin and yang of grasses and trees. When grasses and trees first sense yang qi, they immediately sprout buds; later, flowers follow in succession, blooming and then withering to bear fruit within. Likewise, when one obtains this single point of true yang qi, true yin naturally blends with it to form the embryo. The mutual dependence of yin and yang is generally like this—this is the common Way of daily practice. Yet where the true source reverses, it remains obscure; this is what the common people use daily yet do not know.

Master Shangyang says: Heaven produces two kinds of things—those that move and those that are still. Roots belong to the still, feet to the moving, yet all receive the yin and yang qi. Grasses and trees are still, inanimate things, yet they follow the yang spring to grow and bear fruit. Humans and creatures are moving, sentient beings—without the yin and yang qi, how could they be born and raised? Humans are the most numinous of beings, endowed with the upright qi of heaven and earth, yet they do not understand the Way of yin and yang’s waxing and waning, reversal and compliance.

I now reveal it fully: when qi flows in compliance, it produces ordinary fathers and mothers; when it flows in reversal, it produces numinous fathers and sacred mothers. When the qi of ordinary fathers and mothers flows in compliance, it forms a person—this is the common Way. When the qi of numinous fathers and sacred mothers flows in reversal, it forms the elixir—this is the true source. "Reversal" means the male returns to being female, and the female returns to being male. Without encountering a true master, what benefit is there in mere talk?

If you do not know the inversion within the mysterious,
How can you plant lotuses in fire?
Draw the White Tiger home to nurture,
And bear a bright pearl like the full moon.
Do not merely guard the furnace and watch the fire;
Simply calm the spirit and rest in naturalness.
When all yin dissolves, the elixir ripens,
And you leap from the mortal cage to live ten thousand years.

The Radiance of the Dao says: By human affairs, a man cannot become pregnant, nor can lotuses be planted in fire. Yet the immortals possess the marvel of inversion, enabling a man to conceive—just as lotuses are planted in fire. The sun is *li*, male, yet reversed, it becomes female. The moon is *kan*, female, yet reversed, it becomes male. This is inversion. When these two things invert, the elixir is born; then, using this elixir to refine one’s own mercury and form the sacred embryo is like a male brother becoming pregnant—is this not inversion upon inversion?

The Dragon and Tiger are the essence of True Unity, transformed into two things, positioned east and west, yet when they emerge, they bear different names. The essence of True Unity belongs to mercury, the Green Dragon, in the east. The White Tiger is originally the child of True Unity’s essence, lodged in the west, though its home is in the east. The Immortal Elder says:

Golden Duke is originally the son of the eastern house,
Sent to the western neighbor to lodge and grow.
If you recognize and call him home to nurture,
Pair him with the Maiden to form a bond of kinship.

Thus, the poem’s meaning is to draw the White Tiger home, uniting it with the Green Dragon as husband and wife to produce the bright pearl. The phrase "like the full moon" refers to the method of refining the elixir: first, take the half-moon from the western side at the waxing crescent to obtain eight ounces of yang metal. Next, take the half-moon from the eastern side at the waning crescent to obtain half a pound of yin water. When these two half-moons merge their qi, they generate the elixir—thus, a single grain of golden elixir resembles the full moon. This is the external medicine’s symbolic method.

When this elixir is swallowed into one’s belly, it is called drawing the White Tiger into one’s own abdomen to pair with one’s mercury. Then, by circulating yin talismans and yang fire to refine it, the Golden Liquid Returned Elixir is formed, a single grain weighing one pound. This is the internal medicine’s symbolic method. The "full moon" here refers to the hexagrams of fire circulation: one hexagram has six lines, and sixty-four hexagrams total three hundred eighty-four lines, symbolizing one pound and three hundred eighty-four *zhu*. As for the external medicine’s symbolism resembling the full moon, the *Cantong Qi* says: "The waxing crescent’s *dui* number is eight; the waning crescent’s *gen* is also eight. When the essences of the two crescents unite, the body of *qian* and *kun* is complete."

The two eights correspond to one pound—this is the unerring principle of the *Yi*’s Dao. The immortal master’s instruction on the full moon’s meaning aims to make Dao-seekers thoroughly comprehend the essence of creation and transformation. The two eights of inner and outer must not be conflated in discussion.

Fire here is not the common fire of the world, but the primordial ancestral *qi*—there is no furnace to guard. As Qingxiazi said:
*"The crucible is no metal crucible,
The furnace no jade furnace.
Fire arises from *li* below,
Water accords with *kan* within.
Once the three clans unite,
The two substances naturally converge.
Sealed firm, the embryo does not leak—
Transformation occurs in an instant."*

Gaoxiangxian said:
*"Heaven and Earth in misty union, male and female mate,
The four images and five phases follow in harmony.
Day and night, *zhun* and *meng* obey nature’s law—
Why laboriously watch the fire’s timing?"*
This is the natural furnace and fire.

Simply settle the spirit and regulate the breath, harmonize the civil and correct the errant, and mark the talismanic clepsydra—without the slightest deviation. In less than half a *shi*, the elixir is immediately obtained. Then, following the advance and retreat of yin talismans and yang fire, apply the methods of withdrawal and addition, guarding against danger and peril. After ten months of work, all yin is stripped away, the body transforms into pure yang, and one leaps from the mortal cage to attain ten thousand years of longevity.

This method yields the Golden Liquid Returned Elixir, yet it has not yet entered the profound. One must further refine it for nine years, causing *qi* to return to spirit, to achieve the Nine-Turned Great Returned Elixir of Golden Liquid.

Ziye said: *"Reversing yin and yang"* means yin contains yang, and yang contains yin. *"Planting lotus in fire"*—fire contains water, yin contains yang, death holds life. The White Tiger is the essence of metal: white describes its nature, tiger its difficulty to subdue. The essence of metal is originally one’s own substance, but since birth, it has fled elsewhere. Now, recognizing it anew, one exerts effort to draw it back. Like the moon, like a pearl—such is the symbol of the medicine.

After obtaining the medicine, the method of nurturing it: settle the spirit, stabilize the breath, and let it proceed naturally—this is not what is meant by rigidly guarding the elixir furnace, adding eight ounces at dawn and replacing half a pound at dusk.

Shangyangzi said: Yin and yang possess the mechanism of reversal; the Golden Elixir has the art of return. *"Planting lotus in fire"* is returning *kan* to *li*. The White Tiger is a hard-to-control substance, the *qi* contained by the Great One. Drawing it home means subduing its *qi*—the bright pearl becomes the elixir. Once the elixir is obtained, circulate one’s own mercury and regulate spirit and breath to nurture it. As *Zhuangzi* says: *"The true person breathes from the heels."* Guangchengzi said: *"The cinnabar furnace and river chariot rest idle—
The crane’s embryo and tortoise’s breath flow on endlessly."*
This refers to the spirit’s breath.

Wait until yin is exhausted and yang is pure to become a true person, transcending the ordinary and entering sagehood.

*"Three, five, one"—three words in all,
Rare indeed are those who understand through the ages.
East’s three and south’s two together make five,
North’s one and west’s four complete it.
Wu and ji reside in the generative number five—
The three families meet to form the infant.
The infant is the one containing true *qi*;
After ten months, the embryo is complete, entering the foundation of sagehood.*

Daoguang said: Wood’s number is three, dwelling in the east. Fire’s number is two, dwelling in the south. Wood can generate fire, and the two substances share an office—thus two and three combine to form one five. Metal’s number is four, dwelling in the west. Water’s number is one, dwelling in the north. Metal can generate water, and the two substances share an office—thus four and one combine to form two fives. Wu and ji’s original number is five—this is the three fives. The three fives unite as one, hence *"three, five, one."* From ancient times to now, those who can unite the three fives into one to form the elixir are truly rare.

The *"one"* is the elixir—it is the true *qi* of that, the mother of heaven and earth before their existence. My true *qi* is the child of heaven and earth. Using the mother’s *qi* to subdue the child’s *qi* is like trapping a mouse so it does not escape. The mother and child’s *qi* cherish each other within the womb, forming the infant. The so-called *"Great One containing true *qi*"* means containing the true *qi* of the one. Like a person carrying a child, after ten months, the saintly embryo naturally descends. When the work is complete, one naturally becomes divine and sagely—hence *"after ten months, the embryo is complete, entering the foundation of sagehood."*

Ziye said: *"Three, five, one"* refers to the numbers of the five phases: metal, wood, water, fire, and earth. The *"one"* is the Supreme Ultimate. When the five phases are not united, each retains its nature; when united, they revert to the one Supreme Ultimate. If one can unite the five phases into one, one returns to primordial chaos, and the infant has its sign. Such is the wonder of the meaning of *"the three families meeting."*

After ten months, the numerical cycle is complete, the time and *qi* transform, naturally aligning with the mechanism of the ancient sages.

Shangyangzi said: Heaven’s three generates wood; earth’s two generates fire. Fire’s number is two, wood’s number is three—three and two share the same nature, together forming one five. Wood symbolizes the east, its image the Azure Dragon. The dragon’s *qi* is mercury fire, dwelling in the south, its image the Vermilion Bird. Wood generates fire—wood is the body, fire is the *qi* it generates, thus wood and fire are one family. Yet both are solitary yin within yang, which is why they have different names: *xuan*, *wu*, *miao*—for they possess wood and fire but lack metal, water, *wu*, and earth.

Heaven’s one generates water; earth’s four generates metal. Metal’s number is four, water’s number is one—one and four share the same essence, uniting to form one five. Metal dwells in the west, its image the White Tiger. The tiger’s *qi* is lead water, dwelling in the north, its image the Dark Warrior. Metal generates water—metal is the body, water is the *qi* it generates, thus metal and water are one family. Yet both are solitary yang within yin, which is why they have different names: *pin*, *you*, *jiao*—for they possess metal and water but lack wood, fire, *ji*, and earth.

Heaven’s five is *ji* earth; earth’s ten is *wu* earth. *Wu* earth dwells in *kan*; *ji* earth dwells in *li*. When *wu* and *ji* are divided, the two earths number ten; when *wu* and *ji* unite, the two earths form a *gui* and number five. Earth dwells in the center, thus becoming one five. In sum, this is the three fives.

Thunder-wood and fire of *li* share the same nature, forming one family. The dragon is the gate of *zhen*, and mercury is produced within. Metal of *dui* and water of *kan* share the same essence, forming one family. The tiger is the gate of *dui*, and lead is born within. *Li*-*ji* and *kan*-*wu* share the same root, forming one family. The Vermilion Bird and Dark Warrior unite to generate beings. These are called the three families. The dragon and Vermilion Bird intend to give life to humans; the tiger and Dark Warrior intend to kill humans—this is the law of the world. If one wishes to transcend the law of the world, one must invert and restrain them. To what end is the merit attributed to the two earths, *wu* and *ji*? Metal naturally cherishes wood’s kindness and benevolence, yet inwardly harbors a compliant nature, and thus has no means to unite on its own. Though wood loves metal’s obedience and righteousness, it inwardly harbors a crooked and upright nature—how could it act as its own matchmaker? To bring about their union, the merit lies in the two earths, which convey their mutual affinity.

Moreover, *wu* earth generates metal, desiring metal’s *qi* to flourish and mutually support one another. *Ji* is overcome by wood, so one must first refine *ji* with care to seek the elixir. If one does not refine *ji* and await the proper time, one cannot achieve constant response and stillness. Once the refinement of *ji* is complete, it unites with *wu*. When *wu* and *ji* unite, metal and wood meet. When metal and wood meet, dragon and tiger merge. When dragon and tiger merge, the three fives become one. When the three fives become one, the three families meet. When the three families meet, lead and mercury conjoin. When lead and mercury conjoin, the infant is formed. All arises from this single *qi*.

The Buddha and Patriarchs said: Within heaven and earth, between the cosmos, there is a chamber, hidden within the mountain of form. This is the marvel of the Great One containing the true *qi*. Thus, when the five phases are divided, they are called the true Dao; when the five phases unite, they generate one *qi*; when one *qi* congeals, it forms the infant; when the infant emerges, it becomes the true person.

If one does not recognize the true lead as the rightful ancestor, all efforts are vainly expended. Forsaking one’s wife only severs yin and yang; fasting only empties the stomach and intestines. Herbs, trees, gold, and silver are all impure substances; clouds, mist, sun, and moon belong to the realm of obscurity. Even if one practices breath control and visualization, all differ from the work of the golden elixir.

Dao Guang said: The essence of true lead lies in the two eights as its foundation; all else is not the Dao, and efforts are vainly expended. The *Song of Breaking Delusion* says: Forsaking one’s wife is not the Dao, for yin and yang lose their proper positions. Fasting is not the Dao, for one dies and becomes a hungry ghost.

Master Wang the True said: If a student stubbornly rejects wives and concubines, they fail to comprehend non-action and the action of non-action. The body of the Dao follows nature; all reckless actions—how can they be spoken of in the same breath as the golden elixir?

Zi Ye said: Forsaking one’s wife and fasting—what do these accomplish? Herbs, trees, gold, and silver are material things. Clouds, mist, sun, and moon are external, guest *qi*. Breath control and visualization are all delusory actions. None of these pertain to the meaning of true lead refining true mercury, and they are far removed from the Dao of the golden elixir.

Master Shang Yang said: True lead is the *qi* of the numinous father and holy mother. Without this *qi*, with what would one enter the chamber and apply effort? People born between heaven and earth receive the essence of their mundane father and the blood of their mundane mother to form their bodies. Thus, the Dao of cultivating immortality and becoming a buddha does not lie beyond this. What differs is that one must have the numinous father and holy mother to be true lead.

What is numinous? Constant response and stillness are called numinous; inverting and applying creation is called numinous. What is holy? The initial division of the Great Ultimate is called holy; the tiger not harming humans is called holy. Only with this numinosity and holiness can one know the ancestor of true lead.

Within a person’s body, there is only so much essence and *qi*. If one exhausts them through leakage, how can the body endure? If one treasures and preserves them, the body remains healthy and life is prolonged. If one further obtains true lead and refines it, how can one not become an immortal? If worldly people lack a good teacher’s instructions to reveal the one thing, true lead, even if they practice all three thousand six hundred side doors, they will only suffer harm in vain. How could they hope for success?

The words of ten thousand volumes of immortal classics all converge: the golden elixir has only this as its root and origin. Relying on the *kun* position to generate the formed body, plant it in the *qian* household’s chamber of mutual resonance. Do not blame the celestial mechanism for being fully revealed—it is only because scholars remain deluded. If one comprehends the meaning within this poem, one will immediately behold the Three Pure Ones, the Supreme Venerable.

Dao Guang said: The myriad alchemical classics ultimately return to one principle: all rely on the principle of the *kun* mother’s generation, reversed and cultivated, planted in the *qian* household’s chamber of mutual resonance. The immortal elders have revealed all celestial mechanisms here, yet scholars remain stubbornly deluded, unwilling to seek it within themselves to illuminate the supreme Dao and refine a single grain of millet to become a guest of heaven.

Zi Ye said: She is the *kun* position; I am the *qian* household. Borrowing the *qi* of generation from within *kun*, I plant the numinous root beneath my own garden to form the sacred embryo.

Master Shang Yang said: The marvel of the golden elixir does not lie beyond lead and mercury as its root and origin. If worldly people do not know that the golden elixir has a root and origin, they do not know the marvel of the inner and outer two elixirs. Establishing the furnace and setting up the tripod is external. The *qian* household and *kun* position are external. *Li*-*ji* and *kan*-*wu* are external. Metal essence and wood liquid are internal. Red lead and black mercury are internal. The primordial one *qi* is internal. Though this primordial one *qi* is said to be within, it comes from without. Thus, immortal teachers have the secret instruction of relying on another to plant it.

The *Cantong Qi* says: Cinnabar and wood essence unite only when they obtain metal. It also says: The flowing pearl of the great yang constantly seeks to leave humans. Only when it obtains the flower of metal does it turn and follow.

This is none other than the single substance of lead-gold, yet it follows the worldly method of male and female generation, reversely planting it within the *qian* palace. Thus, Zhenyi Zi says: "It is as when men and women become husband and wife." The true immortals and sagely teachers, in their compassion, have revealed and guided with utmost breadth of intention—yet this risks exhausting the celestial mechanism. How can scholars cling to shallow ignorance, persist in deluded fantasies, and multiply slander to confuse the immortal classics? Know that once the human form is lost, ten thousand kalpas cannot redeem it. One must reflect thrice, observe carefully, and receive with discernment.

Ah! If worldly people were not deluded, each could accomplish this matter. This book, in every place and circumstance, is guarded by a million divine soldiers—how could it be treated lightly? All companions on the Daoist path who, by karmic encounter, come upon this text: at the time of meeting, revere it, trust it, and put it into practice. Do not harbor doubt or hesitation. Cultivate it diligently, and you will swiftly ascend to the rank of celestial immortals.

*Commentary on the "Wuzhen Pian" of the Perfected of Ziyang, Volume Two (conclusion)*
*Commentary on the "Wuzhen Pian" of the Perfected of Ziyang, Volume Three*
*Commentary by Zixian Xue Daoguang, Ziye Lu Shu, and Shangyang Zi Chen Zhixu*
*Thirty-Two Seven-Character Quatrains*

First fashion heaven and earth as crucible and vessel,
Then gather the crow and hare to refine the elixir within.
Once these two essences are returned to the Yellow Way,
How could the golden elixir fail to take immortal form?

*Daoguang says:*
The Classic states: "Sun and moon are the essence of heaven and earth."
The sage compares heaven and earth to crucible and vessel,
And sun and moon to the medicinal ingredients.
Heaven and earth are the true dragon and true tiger,
While sun and moon are the bowstring-qi of dragon and tiger.
The sage borrows names and images to establish metaphors,
Yet the essential marvel lies in the true one’s essence returning to the Yellow Way.

*Ziye says:*
I am the heavenly crucible, that is the earthly vessel.
When heaven and earth cover and unite,
They drive the two qi to meet within the central palace.
Then, with fire-tending and talisman-nurturing, not a hair’s breadth in error,
How could the golden elixir fail to arise?

*Shangyangzi says:*
What is the crucible-vessel? The numinous father and sacred mother,
The heavenly male and earthly female.
What are the medicinal ingredients? The qi of the numinous father and sacred mother,
The essence of the heavenly male and earthly female.
Driving these two substances to refine within the spirit-chamber,
They form the numinous elixir.
As the Yellow Chamber Lord said: "With hands grasping heaven and earth,
And mouth swallowing sun and moon."

To establish the furnace and erect the crucible, model heaven and earth,
Refine the essence and subdue the hun and po.
Gather and disperse, wafting and billowing in transformation—
Who would dare treat such profound mysteries as common talk?

*Daoguang says:*
Accumulate all yang qi to form heaven, which does not moisten below.
Accumulate all yin qi to form earth, which does not flame upward.
This is heaven and earth not uniting—
Without union, how could they engender the myriad things?
Though heaven is utmost yang, within it dwells a yin qi, so it descends to earth.
Though earth is utmost yin, within it dwells a yang qi, so it ascends to heaven.
The two qi waft and billow, and the myriad things transform and mature.
The Way of the golden elixir—establishing the furnace and erecting the crucible,
Refining the essence to subdue the hun and po—
All take their pattern from heaven and earth,
Joining by kind to accomplish transformation.
Beginning with being born from non-being,
Then returning to being born from being.
Formless yet able to transform—
This is called endless transformation.
Such is the celestial mechanism.

*Ziye says:*
To establish the furnace and erect the crucible is to emulate heaven and earth.
Earth above and heaven below is "Peace";
Heaven above and earth below is "Obstruction."
As for the marvel of wafting and billowing transformation—
Its purport is subtle indeed.

*Shangyangzi says:*
Furnace and crucible are self and other;
Heaven and earth are male and female.
The qi of the numinous father and sacred mother in union is called "essence-flower,"
Also named "flower-pool divine water."
Refining with this within the mortal parents’ bodily frame to form the elixir—
All imitates heaven and earth’s creation.

Do not cling to elixir-stoves and waste effort;
To refine the medicine, seek the Reclining Moon Furnace.
It naturally possesses the true fire-timing—
No need for firewood, charcoal, or blowing.

*Daoguang says:*
The Reclining Moon Furnace’s form opens upward like a crescent moon—
This is the yin sea, where the primordial ancestral qi abides.
What need has it for firewood, charcoal, or blowing?

*Ziye says:*
Ye Wenshu pointed to the two kidneys as the Reclining Moon Furnace—
This is ignorance, a misguided annotation that greatly misleads the world.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The Pure Yang Elder said: "At Qujiang, I saw the moon’s radiance gleaming cold—
This is the Reclining Moon Furnace."
The Western River of the Buddhas and Patriarchs—
All are this single aperture.

Within the Reclining Moon Furnace, jade buds arise;
Within the cinnabar crucible, mercury lies level.
Only after harmonizing with fire’s power,
Does the planted yellow sprout gradually grow.

*Daoguang says:*
The Reclining Moon Furnace is the yin furnace.
Within it dwells the yang qi of jade buds—
The tiger’s initial bowstring-qi.
The cinnabar crucible is the yang crucible.
Within it dwells the yin qi of mercury—
The dragon’s initial bowstring-qi.
With the golden elixir’s work of harmonizing and uniting these two bowstring-qi,
A single yellow sprout is planted, forming a grain of millet’s pearl.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The jade buds within the Reclining Moon Furnace are the yang within yin,
The substance within Kan.
The mercury within the cinnabar crucible is the yin within yang,
The fire within Li.
Only when yin and yang qi generate the yellow sprout
Does the elixir form.

Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi—this is what people practice,
Yet only with the medicine can transformation and life arise.
If within the crucible there is no true seed,
It is like boiling an empty cauldron with water and fire.

*Daoguang says:*
Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi—many people practice this,
Yet they do not know these are all postnatal, earth-born, utmost yin substances,
Not the prenatal qi.
The true one’s qi of the prior heavens dwells between indistinctness and obscurity,
Difficult to seek, difficult to see.
The sage, using the method of fire’s transformation, refines it into the elixir—
This qi is called the true seed.
The Classic says: "Subdue qi without absorbing qi;
To absorb qi, first subdue qi.
Absorbing qi does not lead to long life—
Long life requires subduing qi."

*Ziye says:*
The true seed is true lead.
The *Contract* says: "Plant millet when sowing grain;
Hatch chicks using their eggs."

*Shangyangzi says:*
Things without yin and yang cannot reproduce.
People without the true seed cannot conceive.
Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi are one’s own yin—
Solitary yin does not produce; solitary yang does not generate.
Only when yin and yang are true
Can the true seed be obtained.
Ah! How wondrous!

To harmonize lead and mercury and form the elixir,
Neither great nor small harms the two realms’ wholeness.
If you ask what true lead is—
The toad’s radiance shines all day upon the Western River.

*Daoguang says:*
Driving the dragon causes mercury’s fire to fly and scatter;
Riding the tiger causes lead’s light to flash and gleam.
Wafting and billowing in transformation,
A single grain of prenatal qi forms the elixir.
Dragon great and tiger small—
What harm is there in the principle of yang’s nobility and yin’s humility?
The toad’s radiance is the essence of metal and water.
The sage, on the night of the fifteenth of the eighth month,
Unites the qi of metal and wood to congeal the true one’s essence.
Thus it is said: "The toad’s radiance shines all day upon the Western River."

*Ziye says:*
The method of seeking lead to subdue mercury
Lies in harmonizing, ensuring no excess or deficiency—
Excess may harm the other, while deficiency may fail to form the elixir.

Great and small refer to yin and yang. The *Book of Changes* states: "The great departs, the small arrives." The toad’s radiance shining upon the Western River signifies metal within water.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The eldest son of Qian is Zhen, denoting greatness and governing the production of mercury. The youngest daughter of Kun is Dui, denoting smallness and governing the production of lead. When Zhen and Dui harmonize, what harm is there? "Both states preserved" means that since the other suffers no loss, I too may accomplish the work. True lead is born in Dui, and Dui resides in the west.

"Before refining the returning elixir, do not enter the mountains,
For within them, both inside and out, no lead is found.
This supreme treasure exists in every household,
Yet fools fail to recognize it in full."

*Daoguang says:*
The dragon is not in the eastern sea, nor the tiger in the Western River. It exists in every household. Reverse the process and cultivate it, and the returning elixir may be hoped for.

*Ziye says:*
To regain what was lost is called "returning."
To bring back what has departed is called "reversion."
The essence of elixir-making lies in nothing but lead.
This lead exists in every household—what a pity people do not recognize it!

*Shangyangzi says:*
People see only a stretch of wondrous mountains and fair waters and say, "This is a fine place to cultivate the Dao." How many have been misled through the ages! Yet what do great rivers and secluded valleys contain? Only trees, stones, deer, and elk—all of these are not of the same kind and cannot be refined into the great returning elixir. To refine the returning elixir, one must seek the same kind. To seek the same kind, one must hide in the bustle of the marketplace. The immortal’s earlier poem already declared, "Why must one dwell in the deep mountains, guarding solitude?" This meaning is now made clear—how profoundly it cuts to the truth! This true lead exists in every household, in every person. Yet people pass through life as if in a dream or a drunken stupor, vaguely drifting by. Without meeting a true teacher, who would recognize it?

"When bamboo splits, it must be mended with bamboo;
When a hen overturns, it must be righted with an egg.
All else is not of the same kind—vain effort,
How can one obtain true lead to match the sage’s mechanism?"

*Daoguang says:*
If a bamboo vessel breaks, can it be mended with metal or wood? To restore it whole, it must be mended with bamboo. If a hen is overturned, can it be brooded with earth or water? To bring forth wings, it must be covered with an egg.

*Master Tao says:*
When bamboo splits, mend it with bamboo;
When wood breaks, patch it with wood.
A leaking roof is covered with tiles;
A weakened man is restored with the same kind.
To cultivate celestial immortality, one must seek the same kind—only then does it align with the sage’s mechanism.

*Ziye says:*
When the Perfected One of Purple Yang reaches this point, it is as if he advances step by step.

*Shangyangzi says:*
From ancient times, divine immortals have never spoken plainly.
To speak plainly would invite ridicule.
Even Master Cui’s *Mirror for Ingredient Entry* conveys its meaning in just three words:
"Do not use common lead; if you use true lead, discard it afterward.
This is the true esoteric method of using lead—
To use lead yet not use it is the sincere teaching."

*Daoguang says:*
Common lead is the impure substance of postnatal generation.
True lead is the qi of the true one.
Human essence and qi scatter daily, never congealing to form the sacred embryo. The sage refines true lead, captures it, and subdues it, condensing it into cinnabar. Day by day, fire is applied, gradually adding mercury. As mercury’s qi increases, lead’s qi dissipates. Adding mercury and reducing lead—this is the true subtlety. After ten months, the fire is complete, the six hundred hexagrams conclude, lead’s qi ascends and disperses, leaving only a single taste of pure mercury. When lead is exhausted and mercury dried, it transforms into the golden liquid great elixir. The body becomes purely yang, its lifespan equal to heaven’s. Those who study the Dao and reach this point will know the debt to their teacher is hard to repay. They should pledge their hearts beneath the sun and moon, vowing to attain the Dao to repay their teacher’s kindness. To betray a teacher’s kindness is to betray the sun and moon.

*Ziye says:*
The method of using lead is like the snare and trap for catching fish and rabbits. Fish and rabbits are caught by the snare and trap, but once caught, the snare and trap are no longer needed. It is also like smelting silver from lead—once the silver is extracted, the lead is discarded. Those who understand this principle understand how to use lead.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The *Laozi* states: "Heaven and earth are not wholly efficacious; the sage is not wholly capable; the myriad things are not wholly useful." Deeply comprehending this principle reveals the meaning of using true lead and then discarding it.

"Emptying the heart and filling the belly—both meanings run deep,
Yet emptying the heart is to recognize the heart.
Better to refine lead first to fill the belly,
And thus guard the hall filled with gold."

*Daoguang says:*
Guard essence to fill the belly; when the belly is full, the hall is filled with gold and jade. Embrace the one to empty the heart; when the heart is empty, not a speck of dust remains. When the heart is empty, refine lead to control it. When the belly is full, embrace the one to guard it. Both form and spirit attain subtlety, merging with the Dao in truth. Those who refine the elixir must refine lead like gold—do not disturb your essence. If essence is scant, the returning elixir will not form.

*Ziye says:*
When the heart is empty, thoughts are pure, and not a speck of dust remains. When the belly is full, the elixir is formed, and the four great elements are secure. With pure thoughts and the elixir formed, both form and spirit attain subtlety.

*Shangyangzi says:*
Without diligent self-cultivation, one cannot empty the heart of desire or fully preserve essence and cut off lust. When the work of refining lead is mastered, one cannot but fill the belly and fully preserve spirit. An empty heart is always responsive; a full belly is always tranquil. Always responsive, always tranquil—always pure and still. Today, people squander their essence and qi to the point of exhaustion because they do not recognize the heart. The immortal teaches to guard the hall filled with gold and jade—only then can one return to the root and revert to the origin.

"I dreamed of ascending to the Nine Heavens to meet the Western Flower,
Where the Perfected One bestowed upon me the *Finger-Pointing to the Mystery*.
Its words were few and simple,
Teaching only to refine mercury and lead."

*Daoguang says:*
The Tathāgata said: "There is but one true matter. The other two are not the path of the golden elixir." Apart from mercury and lead, there is no other esoteric method.

*Ziye says:*
Gao Xiangxian day and night sought the truth, until unknowingly his soul ascended to the Jade Capital. The Emperor then commanded the Lady of the Western Flower and Grand Unity to instruct him in the secret of the golden elixir. In her text, she said: "Qian and Kun are the gates of yin and yang."

Qian’s Way is male, Kun’s Way is female.
The people of this age know not true yin and yang,
Vainly searching heaven and earth for dragon and tiger.

It is also said:
Shu Tong took up the task, Wei Boyang led the way,
Laughing as they entered the land of Nothing-Whatsoever.
Only then did *Lianshan* compose the *Cantong Qi*,
Left as the king of elixir scriptures for ten thousand ages.
The Perfected One spoke much,
Yet it all comes down to refining lead and controlling mercury.

*Shangyangzi says:*
One who is devoted to the Dao is a person of divine transcendence.
Even in the space between a single breath and a single sleep,
They never for a moment forget,
Thus in dreams they constantly commune with perfected immortals and sagely saints.
Why is this?
Heaven is without private favor, yet aids those who possess virtue.
The Dao arises from emptiness and nothingness to generate the One Qi,
And from this One Qi, yin and yang are produced.
Yin and yang unite again to give rise to the Three Bodies,
And from the Three Bodies, the ten thousand things flourish.

*Daoguang says:*
The Dao is fundamentally empty, yet gives form to qi.
Qi is fundamentally substantial, yet takes on formless form.
When emptiness and fullness restrain each other, the One is born.
The One generates the Two, the Two generate the Three,
And the Three generate the ten thousand things.
The ten thousand things all bear yin and embrace yang,
Harmonizing through the primal qi.
Before form arises, the harmonious qi of the primal void cannot be seen.
Once emptiness takes shape, the clear qi becomes yang, the turbid qi becomes yin.
The two qi intermingle in misty union, their essences conjoined,
And thus are born the Three Things: heaven, earth, and humanity.
The *Book of Changes* says:
"Heaven and earth intermingle, and the ten thousand things are transformed into purity.
Male and female unite their essences, and the ten thousand things are brought to life."
Thus the sage delves into the depths of this mystery to know its source,
And exhausts its spirit to comprehend its transformations.
Therefore, they can return to the root and revert to the origin,
Reversing and refining, inverting the workings of creation.
They plunder the mother qi of heaven and earth to forge the elixir,
And steal the essence qi of yin and yang to serve as fire.
They refine form to return it to the One Qi,
And refine qi to reenter the realm of emptiness and nothingness.
Thus body and Dao unite, subtly wondrous and perfectly penetrating,
Transforming endlessly, now hidden, now manifest, beyond all reckoning—
This is called the Perfected Person.

*Ziye says:*
The One generates the Two, the Two generate the Three,
And the Three generate the ten thousand things—
This is the true body of the sacred embryo,
Though a thousand or a hundred million, transformed without end.
Thus the *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* says:
"In one year, a child is born,
And each one can ride a crane."
The *Mud-Pill Elder* says:
"In one year, a child is born of the embryo,
And the child begets grandchildren, the grandchildren branch forth."
All elucidate the meaning of the Three generating the ten thousand things.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The Dao generates the One Qi, the One Qi generates form,
And within form is contained the original qi—
This is the true primordial One Qi.
When this primordial qi flows in accord, it becomes human;
When it flows in reverse, it becomes the elixir.
Reversed, a man conceives the embryo;
In accord, a woman becomes pregnant.
This "repeated generation" refers specifically to cultivation:
When the elixir is complete, the yang spirit emerges from the embryo,
Recreating yin and yang—
This is what was meant above by "the Three Bodies regenerate."

When the thunder of Kan roars, the golden water flows just so,
And fire erupts from Kunlun, yin and yang conjoined.
If these two things harmonize,
The elixir naturally ripens, and fragrance pervades the body.

*Daoguang says:*
The thunder of Kan is the bowstring qi of the tiger.
The tiger, with the fire within yin, illumines and melts the Qian dragon,
And the dragon then emits the fire of Kunlun in response.
When the fires of these two things merge and harmonize,
The essence of the true One naturally coagulates.
At that moment, gather and ingest it,
And the hundred bones are all ordered, fragrant and beautiful.

*Ziye says:*
The thunder of Kan is water and fire.
Metal and water belong to the Kun direction.
When water and fire clash in the Kun direction,
Gather the elixir to oneself—
Naturally, the true One Qi pierces straight through the Niwan Palace,
Merging with the yin qi within the body,
And fragrance arises throughout.
The fragrance is the sign that the elixir is ripe.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The thunder of Kan is the moment when the other lead’s qi flourishes.
I then seize the opportunity of its arrival,
And emit the fire of Kunlun in response.
This is what is meant by "in a month, there is but one day;
in a day, there is but one hour."
When fragrance permeates the cinnabar field,
The whole body is harmonized and at ease,
The eyes bright, the body strong—
These are the effects of obtaining the elixir.

If Li and Kan lack Wu and Ji,
Though they contain the Four Images, no elixir is formed.
Only because each holds the true earth within,
Can the golden elixir return and revert.

*Daoguang says:*
The *Cantong Qi* says:
"Kan’s Wu is the essence of the moon,
Li’s Ji is the radiance of the sun."
Li’s Ji is the bowstring qi of the dragon,
Kan’s Wu is the bowstring qi of the tiger.
The true earth of Wu and Ji resides in these two positions.
If dragon and tiger lack the qi of these two earths,
How could they merge and cause the Four Images to gather at the center to form the elixir?

*Ziye says:*
Though Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li possess the Four Images,
Without the union of Wu and Ji,
What seeks to return cannot return,
And what seeks to revert cannot revert.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The Four Images are Qian, Kun, sun, and moon.
Qian and Kun are the bodies of Kan and Li,
Sun and moon are the images of Kan and Li,
And Wu and Ji are the gates of Kan and Li.
The wonder lies in each holding the true earth within—
What need is there for excessive deliberation?
If the two families do not each unite with the other’s earth,
How can the One Qi circulate,
And how can the golden elixir return and revert?
*Laozi* says, "The gate of the mysterious female
Is the root of heaven and earth"—
This refers to the two earths of each other.

The sun resides in the Li position and is transformed into the female,
While Kan is paired with the Toad Palace and becomes the male.
If you do not grasp the inverted meaning within,
Do not presume to discourse on such lofty matters with limited insight.

*Daoguang says:*
The crow within the sun belongs to yin, thus it is the Li female.
The hare within the moon belongs to yang, thus it is the Kan male.
To speak without reaching this is to view the sky through a tube.

*Ziye says:*
Li and Kan are inverted—see the notes to the regulated verse.

*Shangyangzi says:*
Li is yang on the outside and yin within—it has an exterior but no interior.
Kan is yin on the outside and yang within—it has an interior but no exterior.
Neither attains pure yang.
To pair Kan with Li is called "inversion."
Nowadays, learners are unwilling to devote themselves to seeking a teacher,
Instead memorizing a few public cases of the ancients,
And in large gatherings, they ceaselessly chatter,
Relying on their quick wit to display their shallow wisdom.

Do they not fear twisting their tongues to no purpose? Even with eloquence like a cascading river, it becomes but a demon obstructing the Way—all the more revealing their base and sordid learning. How then could they possess the eye of the great adept and bow to a teacher beneath the bonds of convention?

The Most High said: *"The knower does not speak; the speaker does not know."*

After obtaining the Elixir, my master, the Perfected Li of Great Emptiness, once heard a temple lecture on the sutras. Concealed among the crowd, he listened, then emerged and sighed: *"What they speak of cannot be practiced; what we practice cannot be spoken."* The Immortal Elder pitied these disciples who harm themselves through profit.

Thus he said: *Cease empty talk of limited insight.*

Take the true yang from the center of Kan’s position,
And refine the yin within Li’s palace.
From this, transform into the vigorous body of Qian,
Where hidden depths and soaring flight are all at will.

*Daoguang says:*
Li has yang on the outside and yin within—it has an exterior but no interior.
Kan has yin on the outside and yang within—it has an interior but no exterior.
Using the inner yang to refine the inner yin yields pure Qian.
The Golden Elixir comes from without; it is the qi of utmost yang, called the Elixir, coalescing within the Northern Sea. By method, it is drawn forth to refine one’s own yin mercury, transmuting it into pure yang. Thereafter, the circulation of water and fire, the extraction and addition—all proceed at my command.

*Ziye says:*
The yang within Kan is Qian. Qian moves and sinks into Kun, forming Kan, while Qian itself becomes Li. The method of cultivation lies in extracting that one yang from Kan and returning it to Li, restoring pure yang. Thus the method of refining the Elixir is complete.

*Shangyangzi says:*
Master Zhuang of Qiyuan said: The Cloud Generals of Primordial Chaos plotted to repay Hun Dun’s virtue. Each day, they bored one hole—on the seventh day, Hun Dun died. People of this world, born from a single drop of true yin and true yang from their parents, possess a body whole and undiminished. Yet by the age of sixteen, just as they have nurtured a body of pure yang, the Cloud Generals arrive: the Six Thieves assail from without, the Seven Emotions erode within. Unaware, when pure yang mingles with yin, the whole body is diminished, forming Li. When pure yin overwhelms yang, the single qi is seized, forming Kan. All ordinary people are thus exhausted. The great cultivator takes from Kan and returns to Li—this is the Way of the Golden Elixir.

The mercury of the Thunder Dragon emerges from Li’s land,
The lead of the Lake Tiger is born in Kan’s realm.
These two substances together beget mother from child;
The Five Phases must all enter the Central Palace.

*Daoguang says:*
Mercury is the Thunder Dragon, belonging to Wood. Wood generates Fire; Wood is Fire’s mother, Fire is Wood’s child—this is the ordinary sequence of the Five Phases. Yet cinnabar, belonging to Fire as Li, gives birth to mercury, meaning Fire inverts to generate Wood. Thus it is called "child begetting mother." Lead is the Lake, belonging to Metal. Metal generates Water; Metal is Water’s mother, Water is Metal’s child—this is the ordinary sequence of the Five Phases. Yet black lead, belonging to Water as Kan, gives birth to lead, meaning Water inverts to generate Metal. Thus it is called "elder begetting mother."

The Perfected of Great White said:
*"The art of inverting the Five Phases—
The dragon emerges from within Fire.
No need to traverse the Five Phases—
The tiger is born within Water."*
These two substances mutually generate, forming the Four Images.
Gathering at the Central Palace, uniting the Five Phases, the Elixir is congealed.

*Ziye says:*
In general, this clarifies the Way of "child begetting mother."

*Shangyangzi says:*
Zhen is Qian’s eldest son, following his father’s will to practice the Way.
Dui is Kun’s youngest daughter, standing in her mother’s place to practice the Way.
When Zhen and Dui unite, Tiger and Dragon descend;
When Li and Kan merge, lead and mercury are born, and the Elixir is ingested into the Central Chamber of Spirit.

The moon, just half-bright after the sky clears,
Soon bears the dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl.
Now is the time to cultivate the work of the two eights;
Within a single hour, the Elixir is complete.

*Daoguang says:*
The Immortal Elder’s reference to the half-moon merely illustrates the numbers of the two eights, likening them to Dragon and Tiger. The marvelous function of this Way lies within a single hour, divided into six intervals—yet the Golden Elixir is established in just two. The remaining four intervals hold other wondrous uses. These are all celestial mysteries, difficult to inscribe on bamboo and silk, transmitted only through oral instruction and heart-to-heart transmission.

Fools without a true teacher claim the medicine is completed in a single hour, not realizing it requires but a single hour. How utterly deluded! The common man, lost and without direction, privately conjectures—how grievously mistaken! To say it requires more than an hour is to extend it to days and months, yet this is the most wondrously simple and easy method.

This Way is not to be heard in the world of men; only those of great virtue and goodness may seek to inquire into it.

*Jin’s note on* The Fire Record of the Great Elixir *says:*
When the sage begins the work, at the inception of refining lead, he steals the qi of the Primordial One’s celestial cycle, seizing the correct tally of thirty million seventy-three thousand years. Gathering it within the cauldron of Qian and Kun, uniting it at the convergence of generation and destruction, he exhausts the tally of Heaven and Earth, the tally of sun and moon, the tally of Dragon and Tiger, the tally of yin and yang and the Five Phases, the tally of generation and completion. Capturing it all within a single hour, he forges a single grain of the Sacred Elixir, as large as a millet seed, weighing one pound—most numinous, most sacred, most honored, most noble. It is the primordial essence of Heaven and Earth, the master of the body’s destiny. Truly, it is to plunder Heaven and Earth, to steal yin and yang, to hold the cosmos in one’s hand, to give birth to the myriad transformations within the body. Attaining the rank of Perfected Immortal, one becomes a guest of the Emperor on High. Thus the Elixir’s completion in a single hour is its proof.

*Ziye says:*
When the medicine is born, it is like the moon emerging at geng and reaching ding—this is the qi-moment of half a catty of metal at the first quarter. At this time, yin and yang meet, easily uniting. By the fifteenth day, the Three Yangs are complete. When it reaches jia in the East, the moon has ascended as a full wheel, the qi-moment of two eights of Qian Metal.

When scholars know this moment and cultivate accordingly, within this single hour the Golden Elixir may be accomplished.

*Master Shangyang says:*
As the moon first appears at the horizon, it receives the sun’s faint yang—this is the moment when the tiger roars and *gui* is born, the primal beginning of precelestial qi. Seize the time when it comes; if the furnace is damaged, recovery is difficult.

The Old Immortal of Ziyang speaks with ever-greater urgency here, fearing that later generations may fail to attain immortality. Yet foolish and benighted men spend their days discoursing on the Dao, the blind leading the blind. They know not what is meant by the dragon’s chant or the tiger’s roar, nor that the work hinges on this single hour. Ignorant of all, they slander the Old Immortal’s words as “Three Peaks sexual arts,” and thus their sins only deepen.

Now, what is this hour?
Ah! Seek not *zi* and *wu* at the far horizon—
Count *kun* and *shen* first upon your own body.
On Mount Huayue’s peak the male tiger roars;
In Fusang’s depths the female dragon chants.
The Yellow Dame herself knows how to mediate,
Sending them forth as husband and wife with one heart.

*Daoguang says:*
Mount Huayue is the western mountain where the moon rises, symbolizing the tiger. The male tiger is the tiger’s first-quarter qi, yang within yin—hence “male tiger.” Fusang is where the sun rises, symbolizing the dragon. The female dragon is the dragon’s first-quarter qi, yin within yang—hence “female dragon.” Though these two are separated by east and west, the Yellow Dame enables their union as husband and wife, giving birth to the Yellow Sprout.

*Ziye says:*
When *kan* is above and *li* below, harmonized by the intent of central equilibrium, tiger and dragon love each other as husband and wife. “Yellow” signifies the center; “Dame” is the term for a woman’s elder years, thus free from jealousy and able to mediate. The meaning of the Yellow Dame is fully expressed in central harmony.

*Master Shangyang says:*
The male tiger on the mountain’s peak is perilous and difficult to subdue; the female dragon in the sea’s depths is treacherous and difficult to tame. Without great power and great courage, how can one master them? Even the Golden Elixir is a supremely yang qi dwelling within the unfathomable and perilous—difficult to obtain, difficult to gather. Without accumulating thick virtue and refining the self to purity, how could one apply the work and attain it?

Now, how can they be made to share one heart?
Ah! If you seek the treasure of heaven,
You must use the wealth of the world.
The White Tiger of the western mountain is wild and unruly;
The Azure Dragon of the eastern sea cannot be withstood.
Seize them with both hands and make them fight to the death,
Transforming into a lump of purple-gold frost.

*Daoguang says:*
Master Haichan said:
“With the left hand seize the Azure Dragon’s head,
With the right hand grasp the White Tiger’s tail,
Bring them together and swallow them at once—
How sweet this thing is to contemplate.”
This speaks of external imagery. The foolish, having never heard the supreme Dao, take it to mean seizing the two beasts with both hands—yet this is not so.

*Ziye says:*
The White Tiger of the western mountain is the metal essence within *kan*; the Azure Dragon of the eastern sea is the wood nature within *li*. These two are fierce and unruly, not easily captured. If one obtains the method to restrain them, they harmonize and transform into the Elixir. This “death” holds profound principle. As the diagnosis says: “To seek life’s wealth and nobility, one must apply the work of death.”

*Master Shangyang says:*
The tiger has the potential to harm—one must consider how to subdue it. The dragon has the danger of fleeing—one must consider how to tame it. Now, how are they subdued and tamed? How do they fight to the death?
Hmph! Seal the three treasures of ear, eye, and mouth—do not let them communicate.
The Perfected One hides in the deep abyss,
Floating and roaming, guarding the compass within.
The Red Dragon and Black Tiger, each to west and east,
The Four Images intersect at *wu* and *ji*.
From this *fu* and *gou* can be employed,
Who says the Golden Elixir cannot succeed?

*Daoguang says:*
When the Red Dragon and Black Tiger meet at *wu* and *ji*, they produce a grain of Elixir, which is returned to the Central Palace. Advance the yang fire in the *fu* hexagram, withdraw the yin water in the *gou* line, apply the work of drawing out and adding—thus the Golden Elixir is accomplished.

*Ziye says:*
Dragon to the west, tiger to the east—thus they are separated. To make them meet, one must rely on *wu* and *ji*. Once they unite, they give birth to the purple-gold Elixir, and the fire is nurtured through the work of *fu* and *gou*.

*Master Shangyang says:*
My teacher, Master Zhao, once saw a man who spent all day discoursing on the Dao, claiming to have met a master who had enlightened him. My teacher bowed before him and asked: “I dare not ask about the Dao—only, what are the dragon and tiger?”
The man said: “The dragon and tiger are within your own body.”
My teacher said: “What do they look like?”

The man said: "They are the liver and lungs."
My teacher said: "You ought to be cast into the Hell of the Torn-Out Tongue to receive your retribution—never again deceive people in this world."

Now, Master Ziyang has pointed out the dragon and tiger with utmost clarity: what belongs to me is the dragon, what belongs to the other is the tiger. With this distinction of self and other, they are said to be in the west and east. The dragon’s head is *ji*, the tiger’s gate is *wu*. Through them, dragon and tiger unite; through this, *fu* and *gou* are set in motion, and the Golden Elixir achieves its completion.

Ah! To know this is not difficult—only to practice it is hard.

First, observe heaven to discern the Five Thieves; next, examine earth to pacify the people. Only when the people are at peace and the nation is prosperous may one seek battle; only after battle is concluded may one behold the Sage.

*Daoguang says:*
Heaven harbors Five Thieves—those who see them shall prosper. If one can perceive them and practice reversal, then the cosmos lies within one’s grasp, and the myriad transformations arise within the body.

To examine the principle of earth, one must first pacify the people. The people are the foundation of the state; when the foundation is secure, the state is at peace. The Sage takes the body as the state, essence as the people, fire as the minister, and the Elixir as the ruler.

We observe heaven with the heart, capture the Five Thieves and practice reversal, plunder yin and yang to set transformation in motion—then the true unity of essence may be seized, and the mercury of *qian* and the yin of *kun* are secured. When essence is firm and qi complete, one will surely triumph in battle and behold the Sage.

*Ziye says:*
Heaven is the heart. The Five Thieves are the five natures of the Five Phases within the heart. Each of the Five Phases possesses its own nature, and thus they mutually ravage one another—all original qi becomes plundered.

Metal governs anger, wood governs joy, water governs coolness, fire governs heat, earth governs stillness—these are the natures of the Five Phases. One who can perceive these thieves will have a heart free of stray thoughts, a body like the Great Void.

Earth refers to the entire body. The essence, qi, and spirit within the body are the people. When essence is whole and qi robust, this is called "the people at peace." When the Four Great are healthy, this is called "the nation prosperous." Only when the nation is prosperous may one engage in battle and achieve victory.

If this heart is overrun by wild thoughts and the root of this body is not firm, thieves will swarm like bees, essence will dissipate, and qi will scatter. To go into battle thus is to court destruction—how could one ever behold the Sage?

This chapter concerns the work of refining the heart, tempering the self, and laying the foundation.

*Master Shangyang says:*
The Way of the Golden Elixir first requires tempering the self, so that spirit is whole and qi abundant, the Seven Emotions unmoved, the Five Thieves unchaotic, the Six Roots utterly purified, and essence unshakable—this is what is meant by "thieves do not raid a poor household."

In the discourse on the Elixir Way, the Five Thieves are: the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and intent as the Five Thieves of heaven; form, sound, fragrance, flavor, and touch as the Five Thieves of the world; love, desire, greed, wrath, and delusion as the Five Thieves within.

If the Five Thieves of heaven are not guarded within, the Five Thieves within will swarm. If the Five Thieves of the world are not expelled without, the Five Thieves of heaven will multiply like jackals.

Thus, when the eye sees form, love arises and plunders essence. When the ear hears sound, desire arises and agitates essence. When the nose smells fragrance, greed arises and depletes essence. When the mouth tastes flavor, wrath arises and scatters essence. When the body and intent encounter touch, delusion arises and harms essence. These five, day and night, ravage the body—how much essence can remain? Once essence departs, spirit and qi follow in its loss.

The cultivator takes the body as the state and essence and qi as the people. When essence is unshaken, this is called "the people at peace"; when spirit and qi are abundant, this is called "the nation prosperous." Seeking the Elixir is like waging war; the primordial unity of qi is the Sage.

To temper the self is to eliminate the harm of the Five Thieves, first guarding essence and nurturing qi—only then can one triumph in battle and attain the true unity of the primordial qi.

The Immortal Master uses battle as a metaphor to instill fear and caution. The foolish, failing to understand the harm of tempering the self and expelling thieves, misconstrue these references to seeking battle, employing generals, and underestimating the enemy as the doctrine of "Three Peaks" dual cultivation, leading to inextricable confusion.

Ah! The foolish remain foolish; the wise remain wise.

When employing generals, distinguish between left and right armies. Though the other may be the host, I am the guest.

I urge you: when facing battle, do not underestimate the enemy—lest you lose our priceless treasure.

*Daoguang says:*
The general is fire. The left is civil fire; the right is martial fire.

"Though the other may be the host" means the host is yang and masculine, fond of contention, while the guest is yin and feminine, fond of stillness. For me to be the guest is to embrace the feminine without masculinity, to maintain stillness without contention—this is the mindset of caution, vigilance, and awe. The art of war says: "Wait at ease for the weary; use stillness to control motion."

The application of the Way lies in fire; the application of fire lies in the person. First, set the water clock to distinguish *zi* and *wu*.

Next, harmonize yin and yang to establish the foundation of transformation. Deploy the sixty-four hexagrams’ yin tally and drum the twenty-four qi’s yang fire. The Celestial Gate rests in the hand; the Earthly Axis turns from the heart. Revolve the seventy-two seasonal nodes’ crucial ford, gathering them into the crucible. Seize the three hundred sixty days’ upright qi, converging it within the embryo. Apply the method with precision; withdraw and replenish in proper sequence. When in motion, guard against peril and contemplate danger—dare not deviate by even a hair’s breadth. Externally, align with yin and yang’s tally; internally, generate the True One’s body. Should one’s mind stray in carelessness or the seasonal nodes diverge, the Alchemical Maiden may flee, the numinous embryo fail to coalesce, and the priceless treasure of the Returned Elixir be lost—just as facing battle without embracing the feminine and underestimating the enemy.

*Ziye says:*
Using the military general as analogy: weapons are instruments of harm, yet skillfully employed, they may preserve life. To treat battle lightly or dismiss the enemy ensures defeat and ruin. When gathering the medicine, divide into left and right armies as with the enemy and oneself. I am the left army; the other, the right. Move with circumspection, reverence, and solemnity—allow not even the slightest breach of discipline, that the treasure may be preserved whole.

*Shangyangzi says:*
The left is the self; the right, the other. "Though the other may be the host, I am the guest" means the other stands above while I remain below, the other seeks motion while I seek stillness. The immortals’ masters speak of elixir-seeking through military analogy: a single moment’s carelessness invites defeat—how could one treat it lightly? The Ninefold Return of the Golden Elixir transpires within half a *shi*, as creation’s forces contend and tiger and dragon wage war. Seize the creative power of Heaven and Earth’s dominion, seize the creative power of the undivided Supreme Polarity, seize the creative power of Qian and Kun’s union, seize the creative power of yin and yang’s unfathomable interplay, seize the creative power of water and fire’s balanced harmony, seize the creative power of the Five Phases’ mutual conquest, seize the creative power of the myriad things’ generation—all converging in an instant to seek the one primordial qi and refine it into the Elixir. How could one not proceed with utmost caution? Thus this chapter specifically illustrates the outer elixir’s symbolic resonance. Should one attain the outer elixir, the immortal’s work is complete—this is the warning against underestimating the enemy in battle. For the cultivator, to accomplish this single feat is to declare the task arduous. The Returned Elixir is indeed the most difficult of all, as the Tathāgata said: "The World-Honored One speaks of this difficulty—it is most difficult indeed." Should one slight the enemy even slightly, failing to guard against the seven emotions or six thieves, the radiant and most refined treasure of the self will be lost—how could one dare underestimate?

Fire is born of wood, its edge concealed;
Without skill in drilling, force not the attack.
Disaster arises from this self-harm—
Seek the Metal Lord to subdue it.

*Daoguang says:*
Fire born of wood brings calamity when unleashed. Essence born of the body, when stirred, must leak. Without skill in drilling, disaster harms the self.

*Lü the Realized says:*
Fire erupts from seven gates—secure them tightly,
Lest it burn through the River Chariot’s path.
This is why one must seek the Metal Lord to subdue it.

*Ziye says:*
Within wood lies fire, inherently bearing this destructive force. Should it erupt, the wood must burn. The pivot of life and death hangs by a thread. The common folk, ignorant of this, drift into dissipation and perversion. The sage, perceiving fire’s imminent eruption, restrains it with water—thus fire cannot cause harm.

*Shangyangzi says:*
Wood symbolizes this body, which grows day and night, and the essence-qi returns to it. In the prime of life, one’s essence-qi flourishes, and the calamity of desire arrives—impossible to subdue. To subdue it, one must first obtain primordial true lead. Yet without a true master’s guidance on the authentic lead’s source and sequence, do not act rashly.

The Metal Lord is originally the Eastern House’s child,
Sent to the Western Neighbor to lodge and grow.
Recognize and summon him home to nurture—
Pair him with the Alchemical Maiden as kin.

*Daoguang says:*
The Golden Elixir’s workings manifest in myriad symbolic resonances: yang within yin that reverts to yang and then yin again, yin within yang that reverts to yin and then yang again. There are inner and outer medicines’ yin and yang, inner and outer three natures, inner and outer Five Phases and four images. There is also the interplay of inner and outer yin and yang. The symbolic resonances reverse and repeat, beyond description. We who have received the profound teaching must not waste time.

Ziye says: This chapter shares the same essential meaning as the earlier one on drawing forth the true essence from the Kan position.

Shangyangzi says: Zhen is the Eastern House, Dui is the West. To seek the Dui position, do not stray from *ren*. Only thus is true recognition and return achieved—yet do not treat the summoning lightly. Once summoned, the most critical step is the return to the dwelling. Alas, every stage is a matter of utmost difficulty; how dare one act recklessly, or speak carelessly?

There exists in the world a breed of hell-bound seeds who, the moment they open their mouths, prattle of Chan and Dao, deceiving others until death without ever repenting—how could they possibly grasp the words of Chan Master Yuanwu? Yuanwu says:

*If the soles of your feet are not vast, your Chan—though Chanless—is true Chan, like a hare with child. If the crown of your head shines with fivefold radiance, your Dao—though Daoless—is true Dao, like a clam holding the bright moon.*

Is this not the very wonder of recognizing, summoning, and returning home?

*The Alchemical Maiden wanders with her own direction—
The forward path must be short, the return long.
When she comes back, she enters the Yellow Dame’s dwelling,
To wed the Golden Elder as her old lord.*

Daoguang says: The Alchemical Maiden is mercury. Her wandering with direction pertains to the workings of the outer medicine. At the outset of elixir refinement, when the mercury fire is moved for less than half a watch, true essence is obtained and consumed—this is the forward path that must be short. After ingesting the elixir, when one moves the fire of one’s own mercury, there follows the labor of ten months—this is the return that must be long. The Yellow Dame is the inner image, the earthen crucible. The Golden You is true lead; the Old Lord is pure yang.

Ziye says: The Alchemical Maiden is one’s own yin mercury. She moves forward in sequence, then returns in reversal. Moving forward, she is submerged in the other in the space of a moment; returning in reversal, she flows upward from below, circulating through the entire body, descending into the Central Palace to unite with lead and form the sacred embryo.

Shangyangzi says: The Alchemical Maiden is one’s own essence. Her wandering with direction refers to the well-trodden path of essence’s movement. In ordinary people, essence is often deficient; whenever arousal occurs, it agitates the bones and marrow of the entire body, stirring the very essence within. As desire stirs, the Heart Monarch is also led astray; the Three Corpses surge above, the Seven Po drive below. Only then does essence ascend from the two meridians, rise through the five viscera to the Mud Pill Palace, descend with the marrow, pass through the twin passes of the spine to the outer kidneys, and engage in union—this is the method of the Five Turbidities world, the wandering with direction of the common Dao, the forward movement of the ordinary path.

The Golden Elixir is not so. It follows the method of inversion, the Way of reversal. The great practitioner, having refined the self to purity, remains unmoved in body and mind; the hun and po are subdued, desire does not intrude, and essence and qi are full and abundant—like a suddenly wealthy household, where gold and jade are found everywhere. When that first yang stirs, and primordial true lead arrives, the essence and qi of one’s entire body remain still. One merely moves a single point of true lead from the nearest place below the inner kidneys to meet it—this is the forward path that must be short. Once true lead has crossed the Magpie Bridge to unite, it ascends with the winch of the Three Carts, passing through the twin passes of the spine to enter the Mud Pill Palace, suffusing the Nine Palaces, filling the two eyes, descending the Golden Bridge, passing through the Double Towers, and entering the Crimson Palace for refinement. This is the wandering with direction, the return that must be long. Then, returning to the Yellow Court’s divine chamber, it conjoins to form the elixir—this is entering the Yellow Dame’s dwelling to wed the Golden Elder, the inversion of the Five Phases and the reversal of cultivation.

After ten months of gentle nurturing, the true person is perfected, attaining a lifespan equal to heaven—this is the Old Lord. The immortal masters have explained the sequence so clearly; the annotations of other schools are all cursory and vague, for they dared not reveal the secrets. I wish for all people in the world, for the countless millions of future generations, to achieve immortality and Buddhahood by this means—I am willing to bear the blame for this revelation. May the true immortal sages above and the gods and spirits of heaven and earth bear witness.

*Though you may know cinnabar and black lead,
Without the firing times, it is all in vain.
It all depends on the power of cultivation—
A hair’s breadth off, and no elixir is made.*

Daoguang says: In the creation of the Golden Elixir, a hair’s breadth of error leads one a thousand miles astray. The sages transmit the medicine but not the fire; the firing times have always been known by few.
