Ziye says: Even if you recognize true lead and true mercury, without the firing times, the sacred embryo will not form. Why? Because the nature of fire is warmth, and it alone can fuse the true substances, enabling their union. Without fire, lead remains lead, mercury remains mercury—each stays apart.

Shangyangzi says: The cauldron, the medicine—these the immortal masters have revealed completely in their poems. Only the firing times are not committed to writing, for they must be transmitted orally by a master. Without the master’s oral instruction, even if one knows the medicine, the elixir will not be achieved. Moreover, the firing times proceed through several stages in sequence—how could a fool’s wild guesses comprehend them?

*The *Cantong Qi* discusses the true elixir,
But does not set the firing times in writing.
To know the wondrous subtleties of the oral instructions,
You must discuss them in detail with an immortal.*

Daoguang says: The *Fire Records* contain six hundred chapters, each resembling the others, in harmony with heaven’s measure. What heaven conceals, the sages do not transmit. If you encounter a true master, investigate thoroughly.

Ziye says: The firing times are crucial to the elixir—without a master, do not guess recklessly.

Shangyangzi says: There are outer firing times and inner firing times. The ancient immortals and sages wrote ten thousand volumes of elixir scriptures, yet none pointed to the firing times—daring not leak the heavenly treasure. Now I reveal the inner and outer firing times, wishing that later learners may all become immortals.

Master Boyang says: *"On the third day, the moon emerges at geng."* This refers to the outer firing times. Master Cui says: *"Heaven responds to the stars, earth to the tides."* These are the outer firing times. Master Chunyang says:

*When the first yang stirs,
At midnight when the clepsydra runs long,
The lead crucible warms gently,
Its light piercing the curtains.*

The above are the outer firing times. Such expressions seem clear and explicit.

Guangchengzi says:
*"Abandon the toil of the elixir furnace and river chariot,
The crane’s embryo and tortoise’s breath flow on of themselves."*
These are the inner firing times.

The Immortal Master’s poem says:
*"Do not vainly guard the medicine furnace to watch the firing times,
But let the spirit’s breath follow nature."*
These are the inner firing times.

Before refining the elixir, the most difficult to obtain is the outer firing times—this is the work of deliberate effort and foundational practice. The inner firing times, however, come after the elixir is obtained, simply following nature’s spontaneity. This is the great rest, the effortless achievement of non-action.

*"On the fifteenth of the eighth month, admire the toad’s radiance—
Just when the golden essence is at its peak.
When the first yang stirs,
Hasten to advance the fire without delay."*

Daoguang says: On the fifteenth of the eighth month, the qi of Metal and Water is abundant, and the first yang begins to rise again. This is the Zi hour of heaven, when both inner and outer firing work should be swiftly advanced.

Ziye says: The golden essence is at its peak like the moon on the fifteenth night of the eighth month. The moon is Metal, and Metal flourishes in You. The eighth month corresponds to You, so this metaphor teaches that one should advance the fire at this time, not waiting until it waxes too full and then wanes.

Shangyangzi says: When Water is clear and Metal flourishes, the toad and moon in the sky shine brightly. When lead encounters the birth of Gui, the medicine in the human realm may be refined. Just as the first yang stirs, do not delay—lest the lead crucible gradually wane and one’s spiritual efforts be spent in vain. The Immortal Master’s poem here speaks of the outer firing times in this way.

*"When the first yang stirs at the time of elixir-making,
The lead crucible warms gently, its light piercing the curtains.
At the moment of receiving qi, it is easily obtained,
But in withdrawal and replenishment, beware of danger."*

Daoguang says: At the Zi hour of the first yang, within the elixir crucible, true lead receives the fire, and its light pierces the curtains. Once the elixir is within for ten months, in the work of withdrawal and replenishment, one must guard against danger.

Ziye says: The learner should seize the moment when the first yang stirs to make the elixir. When the lead crucible’s light arises, true qi is easily obtained. Yet when it retreats into concealment, one must be especially cautious in withdrawal and replenishment.

Shangyangzi says: Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says: *"Receiving qi is auspicious; guard against it becoming inauspicious."* The meaning is the same.

*"The mysterious pearl takes form and follows the bowels to grow,
As yang reaches its peak, yin arrives and gradually strips away its form.
When the frost flies in the tenth month, the elixir is finally ripe—
Even gods and ghosts must stand in awe."*

Daoguang says: "Taking form" means that at the winter solstice, one follows the growth of yang to advance the yang fire, and at the summer solstice, retreats with the yin tally. By the tenth month, when stripping is complete, the returned elixir is finally ripe.

Ziye says: The "mysterious pearl" is the image of the medicine. The medicine cannot generate itself but must respond to the yang qi to arise. From the subtle to the manifest, as yang reaches its peak, yin recedes. When the ten-month cycle is complete, the great elixir is accomplished.

Shangyangzi says: This speaks of the inner elixir’s symbolic process, the work of withdrawal, replenishment, and gentle nurturing. The *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* describes the work of withdrawal, replenishment, and gentle nurturing in great detail.

*"After the first quarter and before the last,
The medicine is balanced, its qi and image complete.
Gather it and return to the furnace to refine,
Refining through gentle nurturing, it cooks of itself."*

Daoguang says: By the thirtieth day of the month, the yang soul of Metal is entirely dispersed, and the yin essence of Water fills the wheel—thus it is pure yin. Without light, it resembles Kun, hence called "dark." On the two days of darkness and new moon, the sun and moon conjoin, rising and setting together. By the second day, the moon is impregnated by the sun’s light. On the third, a single yang appears at the Kun direction Geng—within the po, the hun is born, resembling Zhen. At this time, the golden qi in the human body first stirs, and the medicine’s sprout is new. On the eighth day, the second yang arises, resembling Dui. At this time, the po contains half the hun, and it is level as a string—hence called the "first quarter." The period before the quarter belongs to yang, and after to yin. Within yin, yang is half—one obtains eight taels of Metal within Water, its flavor balanced, its qi and image complete. On the fifteenth day, the three yangs are complete, resembling Qian. At this time, the yin essence of po is entirely consumed, and the yang soul of hun fills the wheel—thus it is perfectly round, pure yang without yin, hence called the "full moon." When yang reaches its peak, yin is born. On the sixteenth day, a single yin arises within the wheel, and within the hun, the po is born—resembling Xun. On the twenty-third day, the second yin arises, resembling Gen. At this time, the hun contains half the po, and it is also level as a string—hence called the "last quarter." The period before the quarter belongs to yin, and after to yang. Within yang, yin is half—one obtains half a catty of Water within Metal, its flavor balanced, its qi and image complete. The sage gathers these two eights, seizing them within the furnace of creation, refining and nurturing gently to complete the returned elixir. The Immortal’s verse here repeatedly exhorts, ensuring one’s single-minded focus. The "cooking" indeed holds a wondrous meaning.

Ziye says: After the first quarter and before the last, following the union of sun and moon, when the great yin is about to be reborn, the medicine’s material is fresh, possessing its balanced flavor. One must swiftly gather it, congealing it with the yin mercury within the body. Beginning with gentle nurturing and ending with cooking, when this elixir is ripe, it will naturally become clear.

Shangyangzi says: The Immortal Master’s poem intends to show that when the medicine arises at the time of the first yang’s stirring, one should refine it, just as the great yin receives the newly born qi to complete the golden elixir. Xue and Lu’s annotations agree; those who take the first quarter as the upper quarter and the last quarter as the lower quarter are mistaken.

*End of the Third Scroll of the Third Commentary on the "Awakening to Reality" by the Perfected One of Purple Yang*

*Beginning of the Fourth Scroll of the Third Commentary on the "Awakening to Reality" by the Perfected One of Purple Yang*

The Purple Worthies—Xue Daoguang, Lu Zi of Ziye, and Chen Zhixu of Shangyang—annotate thirty-two heptasyllabic quatrains:

The eldest son first drinks the wine of the western quarter,
The youngest daughter first blooms the flower of the northern land.
Should the Blue Maid meet them thereafter,
All at once the lock is sealed within the Yellow House.

Daoguang says: *Zhen* is the eldest son, that is, the Dragon.
*Dui* is the youngest daughter, that is, the Tiger.
The northern land is the yin substance; the flower is yin qi, called yin fire.
The Blue Maid is the Alchemical Maiden, the Dragon’s bowstring qi, called mercury fire.
The cultivator of the elixir drives the Dragon to approach the Tiger at once;
the Tiger opens the flower of the yin gate to meet the Dragon.
When the Dragon stirs the mercury fire to join with the White Tiger,
after their meeting, the seal is fastened within the Yellow House,
to give birth to the golden elixir and become a Perfected One.

Ziye says: On the third day, the waning moon appears, as *Zhen* yang arises in *Kun*-ding.
Metal and fire are fundamentally the yin qi of *Kun*.
*Zhen* is the returning yang, which consumes the yin qi of *Kun*,
hence the metaphor of the eldest son first drinking the wine of the western quarter.
The place to which *Zhen* comes is the position of *Dui*;
in this place, yang arises and dissolves the yin qi,
hence the metaphor of the youngest daughter first blooming the flower of the northern land.
“Blooming” means “issuing forth,” and the flower is yin qi—
as in the earlier line, “after the red flower of yin secondarily issues forth.”
The Blue Maid is the wood-mercury.
At precisely this moment, *Kan* and *Li* unite in marriage;
the medicine is gathered and returned to the self, sealing the Central Palace.

Shangyangzi says: Drinking wine in the western quarter denotes the positions of male and female as east and west.
Blooming flowers in the northern land refers to the body’s departure from the names of south and north.
Daoguang has already revealed this in the preceding lines,
and Master Lu again discloses it afterward—
those who hear and receive this should believe it and be cautious.

When the moon of Hare and Rooster arrives in its season,
the form and virtue approach the gate, mirroring the medicine.
At this point, the golden sand should be bathed;
if fire is added instead, peril will surely follow.

Daoguang says: Two is virtue, eight is punishment.
At the time of bathing, fire should not be added.
Ziye says: The method of refining the elixir is this—
when yang prevails, advance the yang fire; when yin prevails, nurture the yin tally.
Fire and tally follow their waxing and waning; this is an unalterable principle.
The months of Hare and Rooster—*mao* and *you*—are the times of spring and autumn equinox,
when yin contains yang and yang contains yin.
Thus, at this time, one dares not advance the fire,
but only steams with true qi to perform the bathing, preserving against danger.
The *Cantong Qi* says: In the eighth month, wheat sprouts—
yin contains the qi of life.
In the second month, the elm withers—
yang contains the qi of destruction.

Master Shangyang says: Punishment is destruction, virtue is achievement. Punishment is peril, virtue is nurturance. Once golden sand resides in the crucible, it must be warmed, nourished, and sustained. Even the Perfected One of Purple Clarity lamented the smoke filling the cavernous chamber—how could one not be cautious?

Sun and moon meet once every thirty days; the method of exchanging days for hours governs the divine work. Whether guarding the city or waging wild battle, one discerns fortune and misfortune—adding to the numinous sand until the crucible brims with crimson.

Daoguang says: The Great Yang and Great Yin conjoin once a month. The sages modeled this, condensing a day into an hour, exchanging months for days and days for hours. When guarding the city, one bathes and ceases the work; in wild battle, tiger and dragon mate. The divine work refers to the measure of advancing fire. If yin and yang are disordered, sun and moon discordant, though the external fire moves, the internal tally does not respond. The secret essentials of advancing fire and retreating water—knowing fortune and misfortune—revolve the Dipper and traverse the Winnowing Basket, covertly aligning with celestial degrees. Naturally, the numinous embryo forms in secret, and the divine crucible gains radiance.

Ziye says: The Great Yin and Great Yang unite once a month. The method of refinement exchanges hours for days, and when *li* and *kan* merge, it is the moment of darkness ending and the new moon’s medicine arising—no ordinary time. Master Shangyang says: In a year, the moon waxes twelve times, clearly marking the days of yang’s birth. In a month, day and night span three thousand *ke*—in every *ke*, seek the hour of *gui*’s generation. In wild battle, one gathers lead; when guarding the city, only warm and nurture. To know fortune and misfortune is to ensure success.

When *pi* and *tai* just meet, the myriad things flourish; when *zhun* and *meng* receive their hexagrams, they are endowed with generation and completion. In this, grasp the meaning and cease seeking images—if you exhaust the lines, you will vainly labor the mind.

Daoguang says: The winter and summer solstices are the origins of one yin and one yang. The *zi* and *wu* hours are the beginnings of one day and one night. The sages moved the tally and fire of yin and yang, harmonizing with the Dao of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent, the principle of sun and moon’s coming and going. Gathering the four seasons, eight nodes, twenty-four qi, and seventy-two *hou*, they arrayed them within the crucible to generate the body of True Unity. Thus, they entrusted it to hexagram images, dividing the work across the three decades of a month to unfold the mystery and clarify the fire phases. To cling to and employ the lines and images is mistaken.

Yet *zhun* and *meng* are the first of all hexagrams, symbolizing the beginning of action and generation, the origin of endowment and transformation. Thus, at dawn, *zhun*; at dusk, *meng*. When *pi* and *tai* operate, yang ascends and yin descends. At the spring equinox, yang qi ascends to the center of heaven and earth, yin and yang equally balanced, forming the *tai* hexagram—like the moon’s first quarter and its qi phase. At this time, yin and yang naturally merge; not advancing the fire phase is called bathing. At the autumn equinox, yin qi descends to the center of heaven and earth, yin and yang equally balanced, forming the *pi* hexagram—like the moon’s last quarter and its qi phase. At this time, yin and yang naturally conjoin; not advancing the fire phase is called bathing. Such is the method and image—why labor over hexagram lines?

Ziye says: When yin and yang unite, the myriad things are born. Born without end, what enables their union is the fire phase. Dawn *zhun* and dusk *meng* are the guiding principles of applying fire. If scholars understand this, the remaining hexagram images will follow naturally.

Master Shangyang says: Before heaven and earth communicate, it is *pi*; when yin and yang have merged, it is *tai*. *Zhun* receives the beginning of generation and completion; *meng* receives the work of nurturing and rearing. This speaks of the inner elixir’s Dao.

Hexagrams set forth images to model forms; grasp the image, forget the words, and the meaning becomes clear. Later generations, deluded, cling only to images, practicing hexagram qi in hopes of ascending—how lamentable.

Daoguang says: Hexagrams are the snares and traps of fire. Boyang composed the *Cantong Qi*, expounding the *Yijing*’s images to illuminate the elixir’s Dao, likening *qian* and *kun* to the crucible and vessel, *kan* and *li* to the medicinal substances. Thus, the four hexagrams reside in the central palace, not bound to the revolving hub’s numbers. The sixty hexagrams are distributed across a month, moving the tally and fire, beginning with *zhun* and *meng*, ending with *jiji* and *weiji*, cycling endlessly like a wheel, turning without cease. Each day governs two hexagrams, thirty days for sixty hexagrams. Together with the four hexagrams *qian*, *kun*, *kan*, and *li*, they total sixty-four, with three hundred eighty-four lines, modeling a year and its intercalary month. The remaining three hundred eighty-four days mirror the weight of two times eight *jin* of golden elixir—one *jin* calculated as three hundred eighty-four *zhu*. All these are metaphors and images. If the fire phases are understood, hexagrams and lines become superfluous. Scholars who instead cling to these and practice hexagram qi, exhausting their bodies and minds in hopes of ascending—is this not pitiful?

Ziye says: The former masters borrowed the *Yijing*’s yin and yang as metaphors, merely to enact one’s own transformation. Those who cling to images and rigidly follow texts, seeking steeds by tracing pictures, are far from the Dao.

Master Shangyang says: The elixir’s Dao likens *qian* and *kun* to the crucible and vessel to make known the male and female. It likens dragon and tiger to *kan* and *li* as medicinal substances, thereby revealing that lead and mercury are the products of tiger and dragon. People fixate on the *Yijing*’s words but do not understand the hexagrams’ use. If they understood the hexagrams’ use, they would not grasp the *Yijing*’s Dao.

To understand the Dao of the *Yijing* lies within the body, not in hexagram qi.

Heaven and Earth wax and wane in their own time—only by discerning their ebb and flow can one grasp the mechanism. Since ancient times, the *geng* and *jia* have proclaimed the decree; when the Three Worms are slain, the Dao may be attained.

Daoguang says: Heaven and Earth are separated by eighty-four thousand *li*. At the winter solstice, yang qi rises from within the Earth, ascending four hundred sixty *li* and two hundred forty *bu* in a single day. Five days make one *hou*, three *hou* make one *qi*, three *qi* make one *jie*, and three *jie* make one season—this is the spring equinox. Over ninety days, yang qi ascends a total of forty-two thousand *li*, reaching the exact midpoint between Heaven and Earth. At this time, yang within yin is half-complete, corresponding to the *Tai* hexagram. Its qi transforms from cold to warm, the moment when the myriad things arise.

From this point onward, yang qi ascends into the yang position, reaching the summer solstice after a total of one hundred eighty-four days, having ascended eighty-four thousand *li* in all. Now, yang within yang is complete, corresponding to the *Qian* hexagram, called "pure yang." Its qi transforms from warm to hot, the time when the myriad things flourish and reach fullness—hence, "fullness." When yang reaches its extreme, yin arises. After the summer solstice, yin qi descends from Heaven, falling four hundred sixty *li* and two hundred forty *bu* each day. By the autumn equinox, after ninety days, yin qi has descended forty-two thousand *li*, reaching the midpoint between Heaven and Earth. Now, yin within yang is half-complete, corresponding to the *Pi* hexagram. Its qi transforms from hot to cold, the time when the myriad things bear fruit.

From this point onward, yin qi descends into the yin position, reaching the winter solstice after a total of one hundred eighty days, having descended eighty-four thousand *li* in all. Now, yin within yin is complete, corresponding to the *Kun* hexagram, called "pure yin." Its qi transforms from cool to cold, the time when the myriad things withdraw and are stored away. Thus, the waxing and waning of Heaven and Earth are revealed through the moon.

The moon begins with the sun. On the third day, the *Zhen* trigram’s *geng* takes form; on the eighth day, the *Dui* trigram’s *ding* forms the crescent. On the fifteenth day, the *Qian* trigram’s *jia* reaches fullness—hence, "fullness." On the sixteenth day, the *Xun* trigram’s *xin* assumes governance; on the twenty-third day, the *Gen* trigram’s *bing* forms the waning crescent. On the thirtieth day, the *Kun* trigram’s *yi* vanishes—hence, "waning."

The sages discerned the mechanism of Heaven and Earth’s waxing and waning, transposing a year’s qi and seasons into a single month. Thus, one day’s birth of yang is the winter solstice. Two and a half days correspond to one month’s qi, so that at the first quarter, yin within yang is half-complete—this is the spring equinox. By the fifteenth day, the qi of the fourth month is attained; the moon’s fullness is pure yang, and yang qi reaches its full wheel—hence, "fullness." On the sixteenth day, one yin is born—this is the summer solstice. At the last quarter, yang within yin is half-complete—this is the autumn equinox. On the thirtieth day, the qi of the tenth month is attained; the moon’s darkness is the end of yin, and yin qi completes its wheel—hence, "waning." Ending and beginning anew, it cycles without cease.

The sages moved the tally of yin and the fire of yang, following Heaven and Earth’s waxing and waning, ascent and descent, and cyclical return. The sixty-four hexagrams model the principle of *geng* and *jia*’s waxing and waning, just as a ruler proclaims decrees to slay the yin worms—only then may the Dao be attained.

Ziye says: When scholars perceive the principle of Heaven and Earth’s waxing and waning, they practice it within themselves, seizing the decree of *sheng geng* and *man jia*. After the new moon and before the full moon, they gather the qi of Heaven and Earth at its fullness, returning it to the body to refine and form the elixir. Then, how could the corpse-demons fail to be destroyed?

Shangyang says: The tide comes in full, the tide goes out empty—this is the waxing and waning of Heaven and Earth. The moon waxes full, the moon wanes empty—this is the waxing and waning of the sun and moon. Spring gives birth, summer grows, autumn gathers, winter stores—this is the waxing and waning of the four seasons. Qi flourishes and is full, qi scatters and is empty—this is the waxing and waning of the human body. *Gui* is born and is full, the full moon recedes and is empty—this is the waxing and waning of the golden elixir.

Master Changchun says: Like the qi of a bellows, when qi is full, it is strong; when qi is weak, it is empty. This waxing and waning of qi is most essential. If one can discern and employ it, at the outset of practice, one must first expel the Three Worms and Six Bandits, refining the heart until it is like the Great Void, purifying the six roots completely—only then may one enter the chamber to refine the Great Elixir.

To attain the Valley Spirit’s eternal life,
One must rely on the Mysterious Female to establish the foundation.
When true essence returns to the Golden Chamber,
A single pearl of numinous light will never depart.

Daoguang says: That which is unfathomable in yin and yang is called "spirit." Responsive and immediately penetrating, like an echo answering a sound—hence, "Valley Spirit." Spirit is established through qi, and qi is born from essence. When essence is refined, it generates qi; qi generates spirit. Thus, spirit and qi are the masters of the body, and the body is the vessel of form and qi. Without spirit, form cannot endure; without qi, life cannot arise. Spirit and qi cannot stand without form—these two things depend on each other to give birth. If one seeks the foundation of long life, it rests entirely on the Mysterious Female. Once the Mysterious Female is established, then long life may be achieved.

The myriad things are born through this and die through this. It is truly the root of Heaven and Earth, the ancestor of the Five Phases, the origin of yin and yang, and the foundation of the ten thousand transformations. The sages relied on this to complete the outer elixir and borrowed it to accomplish the inner medicine. Thus, true essence returns to the Golden Chamber, transforming into a single pearl of numinous light, transmuting the body into qi, and qi into spirit. When form and spirit are both wondrous, they unite with the Dao in truth, hidden and manifest, unfathomable.

Ziye says: "Valley" means "to nourish." The Mysterious Female is yin and yang. If one wishes to nourish the spirit and attain long life, one must achieve the harmony of yin and yang. Only then will the golden essence return to one’s Central Palace, like a single luminous pearl enduring forever.

Shangyang says: "The Valley Spirit does not die—this is called the Mysterious Female."

The Gate of the Mysterious Female—this is called the root of Heaven and Earth. These are the words of Laozi, which the immortal masters later clarified for posterity to establish the foundation. The Mysterious Female is the gateway of ingress and egress within the human body, from which the Golden Elixir is refined and conjoined. Those who undertake great cultivation must first thoroughly comprehend the principle of the Mysterious Female—this is the place where yin and yang unite in essence—only then can one obtain the single luminous pearl of numinous light.

The Gate of the Mysterious Female is rarely known to the world; some mistakenly point to the mouth and nose as its location. Even if you exhale and inhale for a thousand years, how could you ever achieve the union of the Golden Crow and the Jade Hare?

Daoguang says: The Gate of the Mysterious Female—this is called the root of Heaven and Earth. None in the world can comprehend this unless they encounter a true master to instruct them. Since the beginning of creation, without these two things of the Mysterious Female, how could the ten thousand things ever come to be? Both the inner and outer elixirs are established from this. The sages kept it secret, calling it the "sun-suspended, moon-furnace, hanging embryo cauldron." The Golden Crow is the Golden Elixir. With this Golden Elixir, one can restrain one’s own yin mercury, like a cat seizing a rat or a hawk grasping a hare.

Some say the Mysterious Female is the primordial cavity between the two kidneys—this is incorrect. The Mysterious Female consists of two things; without these two, how could the ten thousand things be transformed? How could one point to a single cavity in the ordinary body and generalize it thus? Those who take the mouth and nose as the Mysterious Female are truly laughable.

Ziye says: The previous chapter only spoke of the two characters "Mysterious Female," while this chapter further elucidates the character "Gate," revealing its profound principle. The Gate is the place of ingress and egress, the site of yin-yang union. Without the true transmission passed down through heart and mouth, how could one presume to guess and know it?

Shangyang says: After Laozi pointed out the four characters "Gate of the Mysterious Female," later true masters and immortals were able to proceed with refining the Great Elixir. Foolish people take the mouth and nose as the Mysterious Female and regard breathing exercises as the Way. Such gross errors—how could they ever achieve the union of the Crow and Hare?

Different names arise from the same source, yet few understand; these two mysteries hold the essential mechanism. Preserving life and perfecting form, clarifying gain and loss, the Purple Gold Elixir is most wondrous and rare.

Daoguang says: The *Classic* states: "Nameless, it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth. Named, it is the mother of the ten thousand things." It also says: "These two emerge together yet bear different names." When it is "non-being," the true One qi is invisible, thus it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth. When it is "being," the true One pearl appears in the mysterious void, thus it is the mother of the ten thousand things. In Heaven, it is *li* as mercury; on Earth, it is *kan* as lead. Their essence is one, though their functions differ. Together they are called "mysterious," mysterious upon mystery.

The superior person, the perfected one, grasps the mysterious mechanism of these two to clarify gain and loss, to govern the body. Then form can be preserved and life secured. What is called "loss" refers to the five phases proceeding in sequence, where the ordinary Way has arising and ceasing. What is called "gain" refers to the five phases reversing, where the elixir body remains eternally numinous and enduring.

Alas! The Pure Yang Purple Gold stands at the beginning of Heaven and Earth, emerging as the mother of the ten thousand things—is this not the most wondrous of the Golden Elixir?

Ziye says: The One qi divides into yin and yang, hence the different names. Yet both arise from the Great Ultimate, thus it is said they emerge from the same source. Yin and yang are the essential mechanism of cultivation, preserving my life, perfecting my form, causing no loss to the other while benefiting myself. How marvelous—gold within water!

Shangyang says: "Different names" refer to being and non-being, subtlety and wonder, beginning and mother, mystery and female. This is the place of yin-yang union, the site where the Golden Elixir is transformed and born. Those of superior capacity must first awaken to these two, then they may refine the Purple Gold Elixir.

Beginning with action, no one sees; only when it becomes non-action do the masses recognize it. They see only non-action as the essential wonder, yet how could they know that action is the root?

Daoguang says: The trap and net are still in hand—no one understands me! Once ashore, the boat is no longer needed, yet ten eyes stare in bewilderment. Saints and commoners mingle in the marketplace, fish and dragons blend on the thoroughfare. How lamentable—people of the world pass by without recognition!

Ziye says: In gathering the medicine and circulating the fire, does one attain non-action? Knowing only non-action but not action—how can the elixir be congealed?

Shangyang says: If one reaches old age in non-action, how can the medicine be obtained? Entering the chamber to gather lead—this is called "action." The great hermit dwells in the marketplace—who would notice? To establish the vast enclosure, first set up the boundary. Obtaining the single grain of millet pearl—this is not mistaken. Nine years of sitting in forgetfulness—non-action’s merit is vast. When the three thousand deeds are complete, one rejoices with the multitude.

If one only practices non-action without first engaging in action, this is the delusion of a foolish person clinging to attachment. These few earnest words are offered to instruct later learners.

Within black there is white—this is the mother of the elixir. Within the male, the female is concealed—this is the sacred embryo. The Great One in the furnace must be guarded with care; the Three Fields gather treasures, corresponding to the Three Terraces.

Daoguang says: Extracting silver from lead—this is the mother of the elixir. Drawing mercury from cinnabar—this is the sacred embryo. The two things interact and transform, congealing in the furnace. With clarity of essence and timing of qi, strictly adhere to the method. Without the slightest deviation, the three natures unite, forming the elixir treasure, corresponding above to the Three Terraces.

Ziye says: White within black is the gold within water, the yang qi within *kan*. If one can gather this true yang qi and congeal it into an embryo—this is what is meant by "within the male, the female is concealed." When gathering the medicine, one must keep the Great One as master in mind. If one is not careful in guarding it, human desires will overflow, and one’s treasure will be lost—would the master not find this strange?

Shangyang says: White within black is the yang within yin, the outer elixir’s symbol. The male harboring the female is the yang obtaining yin, the inner elixir’s symbol.

Within the furnace, the Great One must be guarded with utmost care—thus the treasures of the Three Fields gather. Amidst the indistinct and vague, seek the tangible form; within the obscure and profound, find the true essence. From nothingness and being, they naturally merge—how could one conceive of its completion through mere thought?

Daoguang says: True Yizi states: "Nothingness is the dragon; being is the tiger. Nothingness is mercury; being is lead." Nothingness, stirred by being, takes form; being, moved by nothingness, gains spirit. Thus the millet grain in empty mystery shines with radiance like the dawn.

Ziye says: Those who refine the golden elixir must, within the obscure and indistinct, obtain its true essence and true form—only then is the task complete. Without transmission from a master, one cannot rely on clever conjecture.

Shangyang says: The Scripture states: "Vague, yet within it there is something. Indistinct, yet within it there is form. Obscure, yet within it there is essence. Its essence is most true, and within it there is certainty." The Way of the golden elixir is fully contained in these words. The immortal master’s reiteration is most intimate and direct—without true oral transmission and heart-to-heart instruction, how could one attain it through secretive sitting and visualization?

When the Four Symbols unite, the mysterious body is formed;
When the Five Phases are complete, purple gold shines bright.
Once the embryo is shed and enters the mouth, the whole body becomes sacred—
Countless dragons and spirits are utterly astonished.

Daoguang says: When the Four Symbols and Five Phases unite, the essence of the True One coalesces into a millet grain, radiant with purple light. Circulating it internally, when the embryo is shed and enters the mouth, one communes with heaven and earth—dragons and spirits are all struck with awe.

Ziye says: After ten months, the sacred embryo is fully formed, the entire body attains sacredness, and one connects with the divine—how could this not inspire awe?

Shangyang says: Once attained, it is eternally possessed; naturally, the body becomes light. At this point, when merit is complete and the elixir is efficacious, one is truly a great person.

The feast at the Flowery Pool concludes, the moon’s radiance clear;
Riding a golden dragon, one visits the Purple Tenuity.
From then on, after meeting the host of immortals,
Mountains and seas, hills and valleys shift at will.

Daoguang says: When the feast at the Flowery Pool ends, the elixir is successfully refined, the embryo is shed, and the spirit transforms. The skin becomes as pure as ice and snow, graceful as one who rides the qi and mounts the clouds, roaming the eight directions, witnessing the world’s seas turn to mulberry fields.

Ziye says: The Flowery Pool is the place where the medicine is produced. When the feast concludes, the medicine is fully gathered, the sacred embryo is complete, and a body exists beyond the body. One pays homage at the origin and visits the imperial court, the immortal isles of Penglai—there is nowhere one cannot go.

Shangyang says: The Flowery Pool is the Winding River, the gate of the *kan* palace. The golden elixir is formed from this, and when merit is perfected here, one attains the rank of celestial immortal. This chapter is also the immortal master of Purple Yang’s self-eulogy, bequeathed to later generations. For the immortal master is one of the stars of the Purple Tenuity Heavenly Palace.

To know the method of the golden liquid returning elixir,
One must plant the seed in the home garden.
No need for blowing or straining—
Naturally, the fruit ripens and the true embryo is shed.

Daoguang says: This Way is very near, existing in one’s own home garden—one should hasten to cultivate it. If it is not of the same kind, it becomes ever more distant; if one obtains the same kind, what effort is required?

Ziye says: The medicine is gathered from another’s home but returned to one’s own garden to be cultivated until ripe—this is the wonder of nature, not the work of human effort.

Shangyang says: The method of the returning elixir exists in one’s own home garden. The golden flower’s seed can be cultivated on its own—no need for furnace or bellows. When the fruit ripens, the embryo is shed. Those beyond the world—monks in their round hats and patched robes—should know that the wonder of the home garden lies within the marketplace. Vimalakīrti, Fu Dashi, and others all obtained this garden to plant their seeds, which is why the Tathāgata named it the Garden of Solitary Joy.

Do not apply clever deceit as effort;
Recognize the deathless method from another’s home.
In the pot, constantly replenish the wine of life;
In the tripod, gather the returning soul’s nectar.

Daoguang says: Those who cultivate the truth often cling to false and clever methods, applying effort to themselves—how could they achieve success? If one awakens to the deathless medicine in another’s home and adds the fire of returning life within the abdomen, this is the true treasure.

Ziye says: This Way is the reversal of true yang, stealing the life within the mechanism of killing. It is not the three-peak sexual arts or other clever deceits and drifting techniques. Wine and nectar are both divine water.

Shangyang says: Previously, it spoke of planting in the home garden; now it speaks of the deathless method from another’s home—are these not two different things? The wine of extended life and the nectar of returning soul are both true essence and true qi. The Scripture states: "Immortals and Daoists can accumulate spirit and amass qi, making them truly real."

A fine brew from the snowy mountain,
Poured into the Dongyang crucible of creation.
If it passes northwest beyond Kunlun,
Only Zhang Qian will see Lady Ma.

Daoguang says: The snowy mountain symbolizes whiteness; the western mountain is the image of metal. It compares the golden elixir—a single grain, its taste like ghee—ingested into the crucible of creation in the cinnabar field. Kunlun lies within the sea; the Kunlun of our body originally resides in the lower sea of water, where the form resembling Kunlun arises—the place where fire is generated. At the summit of Kunlun is a gate called the Mysterious Gate, also known as the Heavenly Gate in the northwest *qian* position. Zhang Qian symbolizes the *qian* hexagram, its line image true mercury, representing yin fire. Lady Ma symbolizes the *kun* hexagram, its line image true lead, representing yang fire. When fire is emitted from the Mysterious Gate of Kunlun and enters, only then does the true lead within the tripod appear and undergo transformation. As the true embryo melts within and true fire connects without, the *kun* trigram transforms into the *qian* trigram, yin water returns to yang tally. South fire communicates, lead and mercury unite—the root of the immortal’s Way lies herein.

Zhang Qian rides the raft to the Moon Palace,
Encountering the Woman constellation—
This illustrates the meaning of yin and yang meeting.

Ziye said: The *tihu* is the golden liquid within *kan*, drawn into *li*—*li* is myself. Then, circulate it from the *weilü* through the *niwan*, descending from the abdomen to the *dantian*, where it merges with the yin mercury within the body to become one.

Master Shangyang said: Snow Mountain is the land of utmost yin, yet within yin resides yang—hence the saying, "the finest *tihu* pours upon the crown." That which is poured in then reverses to reside above. I belong to the east, thus called Eastern Yang. My Mysterious Gate is named the Furnace of Creation. The Kunlun and Zhang Qian’s Dao-light have already been explained. The Buddha’s past practice on Snow Mountain refers precisely to this. The ancients named it after its place, often borrowing names to represent things.

Those who fail to recognize yang essence and the host-guest relationship—how can they discern intimacy from estrangement? Closing the *weilü* cavity in vain during bedroom arts has misled countless souls in Jambudvīpa.

Daoguang said: Master Zhongli once stated: "The four great elements of the body all belong to yin—what, then, is yang essence?" The true one’s essence is the qi of utmost yang, called Yang Elixir, which comes from without to govern one’s yin mercury—thus serving as the host. When the two long for each other, they congeal into golden sand, naturally unyielding, and so the Returned Elixir is formed. Deluded disciples, failing to grasp this principle, instead practice bedroom arts of controlling women, forcibly closing the *weilü*, calling it "refining yin" to prolong life—this is truly carrying firewood to extinguish a fire. As the *Yinfu Jing* says: "Fire is born from wood, and calamity inevitably follows." How can one not be cautious?

Ziye said: Yang essence is indeed the metal within *kan*. Though it comes from without, it is originally a substance within the body—only a hair’s breadth separates their shared origin from differing names.

Master Shangyang said: Though yang essence is obtained through the bedroom, it is not the art of controlling women. Practicing such arts is a deviant path—how can it lead to longevity? Thus the Buddha said: "Those who walk the deviant path cannot see the Tathāgata." Without a true master to point out the path of yang essence, all side doors become deviant paths. The blind masters of the world pass down the monstrous techniques of "three-peak yin absorption" and "controlling women,"所谓 "the blind leading the blind." When the night of the thirtieth of the twelfth month arrives, they instead blame the alchemical classics for deception, never reflecting on their own errors. Thus the immortal elder reveals this poem:

All things in profusion return to their roots,
Returning to the root and reviving the mandate ensures eternal abiding.
Those who know constancy and return to the origin are rarely understood,
While reckless actions summon misfortune—all have heard of this.

The Dao Guang says: The scripture states, "The myriad things flourish abundantly, each returning to its root." Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called reviving the mandate. Reviving the mandate is called constancy; knowing constancy is called clarity. Before a person is born, they dwell in profound unknowing, merged with primordial simplicity. When they are born, they receive the endowment of yin and yang from their parents. The sage reverses this process and cultivates it, seizing the qi of prior heaven to form the "elixir mother." They plunder the initial qi of yin and yang to establish the foundation of transformation. Refining the form, they return to formlessness; refining the qi, they revert to primordial simplicity. Those who know the constant Dao and return to this knowing are sages. Thus, those who attain longevity yet do not know the constant Dao and act recklessly are the deluded masses, and so they summon misfortune.

Zi Ye says: Even things like grasses and trees can return to their roots and revert to their origin, enduring through the years. Humans, the most spiritually endowed of all beings, move toward death yet cannot match the grasses and trees. This Dao is the way of returning to the root and reverting to the origin—it is not the reckless path that invites misfortune.

Shang Yang Zi says: All things have their time of returning to the root. The perfected person understands the principle of longevity. When grasses and trees encounter the extreme of yin, they return to their roots and await spring to flourish again. When a person’s qi and blood are about to decline, they must seek the way of returning to the root, which can restore youth, revert to infancy, and ensure longevity. Alas! Returning to the root is the returning elixir. "Constant" refers to the worldly laws of ordinary existence. Only by thoroughly mastering these worldly laws in profound secrecy can one revert to the origin and return to the primordial—this is knowing constancy. Thus, those who "greatly conceal themselves in the marketplace" do so to remain unrecognized. If even the slightest matter is not kept secret and one acts recklessly, they will invite misfortune and slander. Therefore, Bodhidharma came from afar to the eastern land seeking to accomplish Buddhahood, desiring to avoid misfortune and escape slander. The Sixth Chan Master concealed himself among hunters in Sihui for the same reason—to avoid misfortune and attain Buddhahood. Later, when Dao Guang Chan Master received the transmission from Stone Immortal, he had no choice but to return to lay life, relying on the powerful to complete this endeavor. Our Chongyang Emperor Lord dwelled in the "Tomb of the Living Dead" to attain the Dao. The Supreme Void Immortal went to the Wuyi Mountains for seven months. The Longevity Immortal Lord went to Luoyang for three years. The ancients toiled and struggled solely for this matter. Yet today’s learners casually remember a word or two from the former worthies and mistake it for the Dao, endlessly discussing it. Then there are the foolish ones who, without studying the conduct of immortals and sages, slander the practice of cultivation, saying, "In this world, there is birth and there is death—how could there be a way to endure forever?" These are seeds of hell, willingly bound to the wheel of rebirth. Next are the attached ones who, when someone vaguely points out a side door or minor path, claim they can walk it. Having never encountered a true immortal or perfected person, they neither know how to return to the root and revive the mandate nor understand the dharma beyond the world, nor do they recognize what "of the same kind" means. If they did know, and could conceal themselves within the ordinary world to complete this great task of conditioned existence, yet still acted recklessly without caution, would they not invite calamity? Thus, the scripture says: "Knowing constancy is called clarity; not knowing constancy and acting recklessly invites misfortune." Knowing constancy is to be accommodating; being accommodating is to be impartial.

Ou Leng secretly transmitted the method for forging the sword,
Moye’s metal and water tempered softness and hardness.
Once refined, it understands the wielder’s intent,
Chasing evil a thousand miles in a flash of lightning.

Dao Guang says: When Ou Ye forged the sword, the Heavenly Emperor sent a divine maiden to tend the furnace. It was crafted with metal and water, tempered with softness and hardness. Once completed, it could slay demons like a flash of lightning, so wondrous was its power. The sage’s work in forging the sword is the same: using heaven and earth as the furnace, yin and yang as water and fire, harmonizing the five phases, refining with spirit and qi. Once the precious sword is forged, it can bend or straighten, soften or harden, do good or evil, be round or square. When the mind conceives a thought or the will directs an intention, it flies forth to slay in a flash of lightning. This is the divine sword. Without this sword in elixir refinement, it is like trying to catch fish or rabbits without a net or snare.

Zi Ye says: In refining the elixir and gathering the medicine, one relies entirely on the wisdom sword to subdue demons and slay monsters. In an instant, it transforms; in the blink of an eye, it traverses ten thousand miles. If the wisdom sword lacks sharpness, how could it not be harmed by demons and monsters?

Shang Yang Zi says: To forge this sword, one cannot use ordinary metal or iron. This divine sword slays the Three Corpses within and eliminates evil without. The foolish use this sword to destroy themselves; the sage uses it to make their spirit soar. Master Jingyang had five immortal maidens play with the sword to slay the demonic flood dragon. Dongbin used the Three Clarities’ sacred sword to erase the traces of spirits. In Buddhism, it is also called the Vajra Treasure Sword—truly the instrument of immortals and Buddhas.

Knocking bamboo to summon the turtle to swallow the jade mushroom,
Playing the zither to call the phoenix to drink the knife-point elixir.
Lately, the golden light shines through the body,
Not speaking of these principles to ordinary people.

Dao Guang says: Bamboo is a hollow-hearted thing, embodying the meaning of non-attachment. The zither produces the proper sound of music, embodying the meaning of harmony. The turtle is the Black Tiger; the phoenix is the Red Dragon. The qi of the dragon’s string is called the jade mushroom; the qi of the tiger’s string is called the knife-point elixir. The dragon and tiger are non-sentient beings, yet they can mate, hence the term "knocking," like two things striking each other. When the dragon and tiger unite as husband and wife, they achieve harmony, hence the term "playing the zither." When the dragon and tiger mate, the qi of their two strings swallow and devour each other. Once the returning elixir is refined, the golden light shines through the body, radiant with mystery and brilliance, wind rising beneath both armpits to depart the mortal realm.

Zi Ye says: The jade mushroom and knife-point elixir are alternate names for the medicine. The medicine is born in Kan, which contains the yang of Qian. Qian is metal and jade, hence the metaphors of jade mushroom and knife-point elixir. Knocking bamboo and playing the zither are the harmonious sounds of yin and yang seeking each other.

The bamboo, hollow at heart, responds with primal desire; the zither, tuned to true harmony, remains undisturbed. This resonance is no ordinary perverse or deceptive sound—no lewd music of Zheng or Wei. Blowing the tortoise to summon the phoenix: that which is rooted in Heaven inclines upward, while that which is rooted in Earth inclines downward. As *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* states, this is the meaning of the "upper magpie bridge" and the "lower magpie bridge." Moreover, Li is the bird, the Vermilion Phoenix of the southern direction, a metaphor for Kan. To summon Li is to receive its medicine, for Li is none other than myself.

Master Shangyang says: Bamboo is a thing hollow within and straight without; if it is not straight, one knocks it to ensure it responds to things. The zither embodies the harmony of its strings and markers; if it is not harmonious, one tunes it to accomplish the task at hand. The jade mushroom is the Qian dragon, while the knife-point elixir is a Kun substance. To call the tortoise pertains to me; to summon the phoenix requires the other. Without great harmony, how could one summon the phoenix? For those who cultivate the Way, once the hexagram qi has passed, if the bamboo fails to respond, must it not be struck? Striking is knocking. If the zither is not in harmony, must it not be tuned? Tuning is playing.

Thus, whether at seventy, eighty, or even one hundred and twenty years of age, one may still refine the returning elixir—such is this Dao. How could mediocre scholars or common men comprehend this? How could false teachers or deluded practitioners ever know it? Without the oral transmission of a true immortal or sagely master under heaven’s covenant, who could attain this knowledge?

Long ago, my master Ziqiong often attended the Supreme Void Perfected One. Once, a disputatious scholar sought an audience, daily striking bamboo, blowing the tortoise, and swallowing jade mushrooms. He asked my master, "What is calling the tortoise?" The Supreme Void replied, "I shall tell you of calling the tortoise, but first, let me ask you: what is the adversary bamboo?"

The scholar answered, "The highest of the highest interlocking mechanisms."

The Supreme Void said, "I do not ask of the highest interlocking mechanisms. Tell me, what is striking the bamboo?"

The scholar replied, "The most profound and subtle of mechanisms."

The Supreme Void said, "These words of yours were learned from those who sit endlessly on long benches. Take them and debate with the world—this is not the place for you to call the tortoise." The man failed to awaken. After Ziqiong dragged him out, the Supreme Void asked Ziqiong, "Do you know striking the bamboo?"

Ziqiong answered, "Abiding in stillness, yet responding when moved."

The Supreme Void asked, "Do you know calling the tortoise?"

Ziqiong replied, "Offering deference to others brings its own reward."

The Supreme Void said, "Why did the disputatious scholar not speak thus?"

Ziqiong answered, "He has not received a master’s transmission and thus cannot force a guess."

The Supreme Void admonished further: "To know is not difficult; to practice is the true difficulty. The medicine meets its kindred qi and only then forms its image; the Dao resides in the subtle and imperceptible, harmonizing with nature. When a single grain of the numinous elixir is swallowed, one begins to know that my life is not ruled by heaven."

Daoguang said: "There is a thing formlessly formed, born before heaven and earth. The sages forcibly named it the Primordial Unity of the True One’s qi—though invisible to the eye, it responds when moved. Descending, it becomes the numinous elixir, like a single precious pearl within the empty mystery. Take and ingest it, and immediately mercury is stabilized and lead transmuted, transforming into a body of pure yang: one’s years then equal heaven’s. Chaoyuanzi said: 'Death and life are entirely the Dao of heaven and earth; one’s nature and life originally belong to mercury and lead.' Is this not proof that my life lies in what I do?"

Ziye said: "The Dao is simply the Dao—purity and stillness are essential. The medicine is simply the medicine—only when it meets its kindred does it form. If one seeks what is not its kindred, one’s efforts are in vain."

Shangyangzi said: "The *Book of Changes* states, 'In the southwest, one gains companions and walks with one’s kind.' If two yang forces are of the same kind, they become scorching drought—how could there be mutual resonance of nature and feeling? If two yin forces share the same chamber, there must be strife—how could yin and yang be of the same kind? Only when yin follows yang does it become kindred; only when lead enters water does it become medicine. The medicine transforms into the elixir, the elixir into spirit; when form and spirit are both wondrous, life lies within me. The radiant golden elixir is completed in a single day—ancient immortals’ words are truly worth heeding. Those who speak of nine years or three years merely procrastinate and delay."

Daoguang said: "The great medicine of the golden elixir—even an inferior practitioner need not exceed half an hour to obtain and ingest it. When I speak of 'a single day,' I refer to seizing that half-hour within it. Once the golden elixir enters the mouth, one immediately ascends to the sacred realm. With such wondrous efficacy, how could one delay for nine years or three?"

Ziye said: "The method of making the elixir fundamentally requires the union of lead and mercury, and in an instant, the elixir’s essence forms. Yet one must thoroughly understand the moment when lead is born—at that time, the myriad things sprout, possessing qi but no form; the water’s source is utterly pure. How wondrous! And what time is this? Ah! It is the moment when this year ends and the next has not yet begun."

Shangyangzi said: "The method of refining the elixir requires knowing the other’s living *zi* hour. If this is not the utmost subtlety in the world, who could attain it? The great medicine’s cultivation may be easy or difficult—know that it depends on both oneself and heaven. Without accumulating virtuous deeds and cultivating hidden virtue, one will surely encounter demonic obstacles."

Daoguang said: "Demonic obstacles lie in the external; cultivation lies within me. With abundant hidden virtue, the numinous elixir may be hoped for."

Ziye said: "The great Dao of the golden elixir—ancient masters transmitted it once in ten thousand kalpas, for it is no trifling matter. The Dao is lofty, and thus demons must flourish. Without the support of hidden virtue, one may suffer the calamity of a broken will."

Shangyangzi said: "Earlier, I spoke of 'my life not being ruled by heaven,' meaning the wondrous workings of creation lie within me. Here, I say 'it depends on both oneself and heaven,' for refining the returning elixir first requires accumulating hidden virtue. To give without seeking repayment is hidden virtue. To accumulate good deeds without others knowing is hidden virtue. To not lead others into peril is hidden virtue. To secretly perform acts of kindness is hidden virtue. Great cultivators who have not yet amassed sufficient virtue are rarely unassailed by external demons. If one can reflect inwardly, cultivate great forbearance, and advance with diligence, then demonic obstacles transform into hidden virtue. The scriptures say: 'When misfortune comes, I return with blessing. When resentment comes, I repay with virtue.' All this is the power of abundant hidden virtue and the merit of subduing demons."

The three powers mutually steal, and at their appointed time, the Dao, virtue, and immortals conceal this mechanism. When the myriad transformations are at peace and all concerns cease, the hundred bones are all ordered, and non-action is realized.

Daoguang said: "Heaven and earth steal from the myriad things through the four seasons, thus there is flourishing and withering, and they cannot remain forever flourishing. The myriad things steal from humans through the five flavors, thus there is life and death, and they cannot remain forever living. Humans steal from the myriad things through the five phases, thus there is preservation and destruction, and they cannot remain forever preserved. When the three stealings are fitting and the three powers are at peace, there is life and death, flourishing and withering, preservation and destruction, things and self—all arising in profusion, endlessly cycling. This is the natural Dao. If one can merge these three stealings into one, reverse their mechanism and act, go against their time and ingest, then the hundred bones are all ordered, the myriad transformations are naturally at peace, all concerns cease, and the Dao of non-action is realized."

Ziye said: "To steal is to take what others do not perceive. The method of cultivation steals the mechanism of heaven and earth, pilfering the life within death. When one grasps this principle, the hundred bones are at peace."

Lord Shangyang said: "The term 'stealing' is not what the vulgar world calls theft. It is the method of the Golden Elixir, stealing that primordial, pre-heaven and pre-earth spark of true yang’s inception-qi to refine the Returned Elixir. Only those of lofty Dao and weighty virtue—those who are among the immortals—can conceal and employ this mechanism. It is not something those of slanderous virtue and corrupt conduct, or mediocre people, can know. Even if they chance to know it, they either doubt or are deluded. Why? Because they lack virtue. Thus, the immortals of Dao and virtue conceal this mechanism.

*The Three Strategies* contains over three hundred treasured characters; *The Scripture of Dao and Virtue* holds five thousand numinous words. Countless immortals of past and present have all, through this, attained the true explanation.

Daoguang said: "These two scriptures are the pivot of all scriptures, the linchpin controlling the mechanisms of all masters."

Lord Shangyang said: "*The Three Strategies* and *The Scripture of Dao and Virtue* are the ancestral texts of the Elixir. All immortals have revered them as stepping-stones, cultivating them to achieve the Dao. Yet their meaning is profound and distant; the world is shallow, people frivolous, and few can grasp this. Thus, the immortal master composed *Awakening to Reality*, so that later learners, upon seeing it, would be immediately enlightened, easily comprehending and practicing it. Know then that *The Three Strategies*, *The Scripture of Dao and Virtue*, and *Awakening to Reality*—these three books speak of one and the same matter.

Though your wisdom surpasses Yan and Min,
Without a radiant teacher, do not force your guesses.
For the Golden Elixir has no oral transmission—
Where then can you conceive the numinous embryo?

Daoguang said: "A thousand scriptures and ten thousand treatises merely spread branches and leaves. The supreme Dao is not complex—it is uniquely transmitted as the mind-seal. Without encountering a true teacher, forced guesses will not suffice."

Ziye said: "Without the true essentials from a teacher’s oral transmission, where can one begin?"

Lord Shangyang said: "The nine schools and hundred arts can all be left on paper, or known through clever guesses and wisdom. Only the matter of the Golden Elixir cannot be grasped by force of will without a true teacher’s step-by-step guidance. Some may receive a teacher’s brief words on the crucible but not know the time when the medicine arises—this will not produce the Elixir. Knowing the medicine but not the firing times will not produce the Elixir. Knowing the firing times but not the inversion will not produce the Elixir. Knowing the inversion but not the subtle refinement of the self will not produce the Elixir. Knowing the refinement of the self but not the dual use of method and resources will not produce the Elixir. Master Cui’s *Mirror for Ingesting the Medicine* states: 'A deviation by a hair’s breadth will fail to produce the Elixir.'

Alas! The foolish of the world rely on their wit, seeking to understand through words. They trust their cleverness, attempting to grasp it through the mind. Some, through perverse means, practice 'exploratory battles'; others merely sit in dry emptiness. The immortal master’s compassion is boundless; his verses are urgent, and many later seekers have benefited.

Once the mind-monkey is thoroughly tamed and the mechanism of the square inch is stilled,
Three thousand merits and deeds align with heaven.
Naturally, the crucible simmers dragon and tiger—
Why cling to home, long for wife and child?

Daoguang said: "These words are most earnest—why do people not turn back?"

Lord Shangyang said: "Heaven and earth’s work: spring births, summer grows, autumn harvests, winter seals. The flourishing and withering of the myriad things, the revolutions of the stars—creation’s turning completes its cycle in just three hundred sixty days. For the cultivator, restraining the mind-monkey, cleansing the square inch, retrieving the jewel from the river of desire—this takes but half a double-hour. Guarding the Returned Elixir within the chamber of spirit for some three thousand days, merits fill creation, virtue subdues ghosts and spirits—is this not merit and deeds aligning with heaven?

Before refining the Returned Elixir, hasten to begin—
Time waits for no one.
Once refined, know when to stop.
If you cling to fullness with an insatiable heart,
You may one day suffer disgrace.

Daoguang said: "If the Elixir is not yet refined, hasten to begin—time does not wait. Once the Elixir is refined, embrace oneness and guard completion, facing the wall for nine years—thus the Dao is magnified."

Lord Shangyang said: "Before refining the Returned Elixir, hasten to refine it. Once the Elixir is refined, hasten to leave it. The Buddha said: 'After achieving the Dao, abandon the alchemical chamber and its vessels.' If you do not leave them, the mind’s realm will appear before you, and the two fears may bring disgrace. The Perfected One of Purple Clarity and White Truth, at midnight, suddenly encountered wind and thunder—this is the proof. Thus, Bodhidharma left the long robe and sat coldly in Shaolin, free from any day’s calamity.

You must turn the door of death into the door of life—
Do not cling to the gate of life as the gate of death.
If you grasp the mechanism of killing and understand reversal,
You will know that harm conceals grace.

Daoguang said: "The five phases, in sequence, bring life; in reversal, bring death—this is the common Dao. Life that does not generate is long life; compliance that is not compliance is supreme compliance—this is the Elixir Dao. If you can understand this, then harm conceals grace, and a man may conceive."

Lord Shangyang said: "The poem says: 'Illumine the gates and doors, urgently repair them.' If people today grasp this principle, understand the mechanism of life and death, recognize the use of inversion, know the wonder of return, and transform the gate of life and killing—turning suffering into joy, enduring to gather grace—what worry is there of not attaining immortality?

Fortune and misfortune arise mutually, interdependent,
Like echoes and shadows following one another.
If you can turn this mechanism of life and killing,
In the space of a hand’s turn, calamity becomes blessing.

Daoguang said: "Yang governs life and is called fortune; yin governs killing and is called misfortune. When yin diminishes, yang grows; when yang reaches its peak, yin arises—mutually interdependent, this is the common Dao. If you cultivate by reversing the mechanism of life and killing, in the space of a hand’s turn, calamity becomes blessing, harm conceals grace, a man may conceive—this is the Elixir Dao."

Ziye said: "The five phases in sequence are the fire-pit of the dharma-realm. The five phases in inversion are the seven treasures of the great earth."

Lord Shangyang said: "Creation is in the grasp of my palm; fortune and misfortune are cultivated by me."

Flowing with it, one becomes human; reversing it, one births the Elixir.
The world’s people, not knowing how to turn the mechanism of life and killing,
Thus spin in the wheel of rebirth without end.
How could they know the Dao of becoming Buddha or Immortal lies but in a hand’s turn?

In cultivation, blend with the vulgar yet harmonize one’s radiance—
Round when round, square when square.
Manifest or hidden, yielding or resisting—none can fathom,
How could men perceive the Unconcealed?

Daoguang said: *The Laozi* states: "Harmonize its radiance, blend with its dust."
Harmonizing and blending the boundary between heaven and humanity
Is the true secret essential of cultivation.

Ziye said: Outer roundness, inner squareness—this is the realm of deliberate action.
How could the Dao’s meaning be made visible to others?

Lord Shangyang said: The immortal masters, in their vast compassion,
Not only reveal the secrets of the Golden Elixir to awaken later generations,
But also repeatedly exhort them with worldly teachings—how earnest they are!
For the Golden Elixir, the greatest difficulty lies in blending with the vulgar.
The deepest subtlety lies in harmonizing one’s radiance.
Though possessing wondrous efficacy, one does not display sharp edges—
Adapting to the world with roundness and squareness,
Subtly shaping transformation without revealing it.
At this stage, who can discern one’s actions or concealment?
All these are truly the highest matters of great cultivation.

Lord Daoguang, upon hearing the words of Apricot Grove, cast off his monastic robes and returned to lay life to fulfill the great matter—was this not blending with the vulgar? The Sixth Patriarch, upon receiving the Fifth Patriarch’s teaching, entered among hunters, unknown to all—was this not blending with the vulgar? Our Great Void Perfected One, having received the wondrous instructions of Master Yellow Chamber, withdrew to seclude himself in Mount Wuyi for seven months before attaining the Dao—was this not harmonizing one’s radiance?

Yet today’s yellow-robed and black-clad followers, shaving their crowns and donning patched robes, coiling their topknots and squaring their cassocks—do they truly comprehend the great sigh of our sagely teaching on the burden of possessing a body? How could they know that this very bodily form becomes the greatest obstacle to entering the chamber?

Thus, the great hermit in the marketplace dust makes himself unfathomable to others. Those who cultivate the Dharma beyond the world ensure that none can discern their actions or concealment. As Laozi said: *"When you greet it, you do not see its head; when you follow it, you do not see its rear."* And again: *"Only because it cannot be known is it forced to take on form."*

Having attained this clarity, one looks back at the foolish common folk who seek the Dao through cunning schemes, shallow knowledge, and wanton indulgence—they are farther from it than ever. For those of great cultivation who have reached this stage, should they not repeatedly ponder this poem to achieve the meritorious work of the Dao?

*Five-Character Verse—Symbolizing the Wondrousness of the Great One Containing True Qi*
A maiden dons azure robes,
A young lord wears white silk.
Seen, it cannot be used;
Used, it cannot be seen.
In vagueness they meet,
In darkness transformations arise.
In a flash, flames soar—
The true person naturally appears.

Lord Daoguang said: The maiden is the latent *qi* of the dragon, called Wood Maiden, born of the Azure Dragon—hence she wears azure robes. The young lord is the latent *qi* of the tiger, called Metal Lord, born of the White Tiger—hence he wears white silk. That which has form and can be seen belongs to the dross of later heaven and cannot be used. Only the primordial true unified *qi*, born before heaven and earth, dwelling in vagueness, emerging from darkness, boundless and expansive, spiritually transforming, giving birth to being from non-being—when the fire practice is rectified, the true person appears. This is the wondrousness of the Dao. Without encountering a true master to personally transmit the oral instructions, who could attain this?

Ziye said: The maiden in azure robes is Wood Mercury. The young lord in white silk is Water Metal. When yin and yang unite, their unmanifested *qi* intermingles in darkness and vagueness—only then can it be used. Once form appears, it becomes later heaven and cannot be used.

Lord Shangyang said: These eight lines of verse encompass the wondrous workings of an entire alchemical classic. The first line concerns the affairs of the *Zhen* palace, Wood Mercury, belonging to oneself. The second line concerns the affairs of the *Dui* palace, Lead, belonging to the other. The third line gives birth to beings; the fourth refines the elixir. The fifth line enters the chamber to begin work; the sixth guards against danger. The seventh line is the elixir’s ninefold transmutation; the eighth, the completion of three thousand merits. The immortal master composed this poem solely to point out the primordial true unified *qi*—the initial *qi* contained by the Great One. Should the scholar not seek a master?

*Twelve "Moon over the West River" Verses—Symbolizing the Twelve Months*
The immortal master said: *West* is the direction of metal. *River* is the essence of water. *Moon* is the function of the elixir. The inner medicine is like the outer medicine; if the inner is open, the outer must also be open. The elixir’s essence harmonizes with like kinds—its nurturing employs two distinct functions. Within, there is the celestial true fire, blazing red in the furnace. Without, the outer furnace’s increase and decrease require diligent effort. No wonder is greater than the true seed.

Lord Daoguang said: The *Breaking Delusion Song* of the Gate of Yi states: *"The Dao is within—set up the furnace; the tripod is without. The Dao is without—Kan and Li; lead and mercury are within."* This clarifies the two medicines, inner and outer. The outer medicine is the Golden Elixir. Its transformation occurs in the furnace of the two eights, taking no more than half a double-hour to mature. The inner medicine is the Golden Liquor Returning Elixir. Its transformation occurs within one’s own body, requiring a full ten months before the embryo can shed its mortal form and become a sage. Though the two medicines’ functions are somewhat alike, their fire times in practice are vastly different.

When we disciples work on the outer elixir, at the moment of harmonizing the elixir’s essence, the slightest error prevents the great medicine from forming. When harmonizing the inner elixir’s essence, one must be most cautious to guard against danger. Though the inner elixir possesses celestial true fire, blazing red within the earthen crucible, one must still diligently adjust the outer furnace’s fire. Yet the endless transformations of the inner and outer true fires truly rely on the wondrousness of true lead. This substance alone can capture mercury and prevent it from flying away.

Master Ye Wenshu, failing to grasp this principle, claimed that the inner medicine is refined by true fire, while the outer medicine requires the addition of mundane fire. Alas! He had not received a master’s guidance and merely peered at the heavens through a tube. He did not understand that though the two medicines differ in being inner and outer, their function follows a single path.

The reason for inner and outer lies in this: a person’s body, endowed with the finest *qi* of heaven and earth, is born and entrusted to yin and yang to be cast into illusory form. Thus, within this single form, essence, *qi*, and spirit are primary. Spirit is born of *qi*, *qi* is born of essence, and essence is born of spirit. If a cultivator of the elixir clings to this body and practices within it, they do no more than refine the three substances of essence, *qi*, and spirit. Yet these three are all born of later heaven and earth, purely yin without yang. How could refining them enable one to transcend heaven and earth?

Master Zhongli said: *"Tears, saliva, essence, fluids, *qi*, blood, and marrow—these seven substances are all yin."*

It is further said: *"To refine but a single substance is to nurture solitary yin."*

The sage knows that one’s true essence, born after heaven and earth, belongs to yin—difficult to seize, easy to lose. Thus, one must seek the primordial *qi* of prior heaven, capturing in a single moment the true yin and true yang, the twofold and eightfold substances of the same kind, to refine them into a single grain. This is called the Elixir of Supreme Yang, known as True Lead. Its creation lies without, hence it is called the Outer Medicine. Then, with this Yang Elixir, one seizes one’s own yin mercury, like a cat catching a mouse. The Yang Elixir is the mother-*qi* of heaven and earth, while one’s own mercury is the child-*qi* of heaven and earth. To subdue the child-*qi* with the mother-*qi*—is this not of the same kind? Its creation lies within, hence it is called the Inner Medicine.

Thereupon, borrowing the fire of yin-yang tally, one applies the methods of withdrawal and addition. After ten months, the work is complete: form transforms into *qi*, *qi* transforms into spirit, and spirit merges with the Dao. Ascending into the formless, one’s transformations become unfathomable. Thus, one transcends heaven and earth, stands beyond the realm of creation, and grasps heaven and earth to mold yin and yang—yet is not molded by yin and yang. This is the work of the primordial *qi* of prior heaven.

Such wondrous subtlety is unparalleled, for nothing surpasses the true seed. How could one use the ordinary lead, mercury, cinnabar, or fire of later heaven—impure substances of a different kind—as the Outer Medicine?

Scholars of the Dao must delve into the root and origin, meticulously distinguishing between the true and the false. Let none be deceived by fraudulent pretenders who feign lofty attainment to mislead later generations. Those who do so shall forever sink into the Three Wretched Realms.

Ziye said: *"The Way of the Inner Elixir closely resembles the work of the Outer Medicine and furnace-fire. Generally, mercury cannot be subdued without lead. He who understands the outer work will easily grasp the inner."*

Shangyangzi said: *"Those who cultivate the Dao must first thoroughly comprehend the true workings of the two yin and yang—inner and outer. Then, when entering the chamber to begin the work, success will come easily. The Inner Medicine is what one inherently possesses, while the Outer Medicine is what the body produces. The Inner Medicine resides within oneself, while the Outer Medicine emerges from one’s form. The Inner Medicine does not depart from one’s body, just as the Outer Medicine does not depart from one’s appearance. The Inner Medicine completes one’s nature, while the Outer Medicine fulfills both nature and life. The Inner Medicine is essence, the Outer Medicine is *qi*. Essence and *qi* do not part, hence they are called the true seed. Only when nature and life are cultivated together can one attain the rank of Heavenly Immortal."*

This Dao is most divine and sagely—lest one’s meager allotment prove insufficient to bear its marvels. When lead and mercury are harmonized, the work is not even a full morning’s labor, and soon the first signs of the Mysterious Pearl appear. If a determined practitioner refines this, why should they not dwell in the marketplace or court? The work is easy, the medicine not distant—yet to speak of it makes others laugh.

Daoguang said: *"When the Golden Elixir enters the mouth, one instantly ascends to sagehood—is this not most divine and sagely? The refinement takes but half an hour—is this not most simple and easy? It is found in every household, unrestricted by marketplace or court—is this not most near? Precisely because it is so near, to speak of it makes others laugh. Those who attain it need only fear lacking merit or virtue, forgetting their teacher, or turning from the Dao—such would be unworthy of its wonder."*

Ziye said: *"The matter of the Golden Elixir is called divine and sagely because of its supreme efficacy. Its efficacy is like standing a pole to cast a shadow or calling into a valley to hear an echo—not some empty, illusory art. This Golden Elixir consists solely of lead and mercury: lead comes from without, mercury arises from within. Once the willing heart is discerned, the Mysterious Pearl takes form. The work is easy—why seek secluded mountains and marshes for refinement?"*

Shangyangzi said: *"The Way of the Returned Elixir lies in subduing the dragon and taming the tiger, stealing the creative power of heaven and earth—how wondrous and divine! Motionless in stillness, yet responsive when moved—how spiritually efficacious! Those who hear and believe, receiving and practicing diligently, are of great root and superior capacity. Those who hear and laugh in scorn are of meager allotment and poor fortune. When lead and mercury unite and the Mysterious Pearl appears, this is called the Golden Elixir. This Elixir is present in the marketplace and home, in daily use and nightly labor—inherently complete, without constraint.
